name: Marissa Paykos
bio: Life through the eyes of the Executive in Overalls, owner of Whippoorwill Farms SC, a commercial, bio diverse regenerative farm in SC.  #1243437

social_posts.post_text:
Someone asked me the other day if the chicken thighs they were buying from me, were going to be life changing.  Even after seeing the per pound price, their total jarred them.  I looked them in the eye and said,

“Life changing, in what way?  If you mean life changing, in taste, like they are going to be the most delicious thing you’ve ever eaten, then no, they won’t change your life in that way.  They are chicken thighs, not magic.

But if you mean life changing like, the employees on my farm are paid a very fair living wage while doing work they believe in, then yes, your purchase is life changing to them.

If you mean life changing, like the livestock raised on our farm is raised under the highest humane and environmental standards, then yes, your purchase is life changing to them and supports livestock raised in incredible conditions.

If you mean life changing, like the people that own this farm, myself and my husband and my daughter, are paid enough so our business can remain viable for years to come so we can continue to serve our community the most healthy, nutrient dense food, then yes, your purchase is life changing to us.

If you mean life changing, for yourself, for the nutrients that this food will give you, then yes, your purchase will change your life in providing you with true nutrients your body needs, more so than any label could promise from the grocery store.

Lastly, if you mean life changing, like our farming practices not only help keep the natural cycles of the earth in place, but help to regenerate them, then yes, your purchase is life changing for everyone on this planet, including you.

So is it life changing in how you thought it would be?  No.  It will be life changing in so many more valuable ways then you could have ever imagined.”

It’s time as a collective that we start making choices that change lives.

—————-

Marissa and Ellie for @duluthtradingcompany and @duluthwomen

Photos credited to @tomrafalovich

This is eight.

When James and I first started talking, before we even kissed, he would talk about how he wished he wasn’t so much older than me, how much more we could’ve shared together if only he was my age. A lot of those original conversations revolved around us saying our relationship would never work because of our age difference. A lot of those conversations were him telling me he didn’t want to hold me back because I still had so much life left to live, I had so much yet to experience.

Eventually though, we decided that if we were happy, if even for a year, if that’s all we shared, it would be worth it.  So we gave in.

One day after that conversation when we decided to just let it go, we were driving into Savannah. I asked, “what’s something you’ve always wanted that you never had?” He said, “a family. Like a real family, who stays together, raises their kids together, loves each other truly, works hard together, has common goals.” I kind of looked at him, taken a back because most men don’t say such deep things.  He continued, “I’d love to have a family with you, but I know I’m probably too much older.” To lighten the mood and give myself a breather from the heavy answer, I said, “yeah, you’re right…you’re too old to get me pregnant anyway,” I said with a side glance and a smile.  James doesn’t like to be told he can’t do something and he immediately challenged it.  So I told him, “I’ll bet you, you can’t.” And it was on from there.

It wasn’t long after that bet, he proved to me, he sure could get me pregnant 😂 and 9 months after that, the sweetest little girl arrived who came out looking JUST like him. 8 years later, she still looks just like him. But worse, she acts just like him too 😂 challenging me always, betting me, proving to me and teaching me along the way.  She is the bet I lost, that I’d lose 1000 times over again and and again.

Happy 8th Birthday to our little wild child. The girl who got a brand new outfit to wear from her grandma yesterday when she “goes somewhere nice” and decided getting to ride in her daddy’s new truck and go fishing was occasion enough. Stay simple and sweet, girl.  But give ‘em hell too.  We love you, El!

Growing Sunflowers?

Harvest when:
1. Petals are just starting to peak open
2. Centers are nice and tight and not fuzzy yet

If you’re like me and some times miss a bloom or two, just leave them for the pollinators!  They’ll thank you for it. Other sunflowers to leave would be any missing petals or with petals that were a snack for the local insect or deer population.

Always let your flowers dry from the morning dew or rain before putting into refrigeration!

And if you’re a shopper, look for tight, non fuzzy centers and a mix of mostly open and just starting to open blooms to give you the longest vase life for your cut flowers!  If the flowers already have fuzzy centers, pass them up because they won’t last nearly as long as flowers with nice, tight centers!

She told me that picking the first ripe cherry tomatoes of 2023 “brightened her day”. Then she told me that she didn’t care if the tomatoes were ripe or not, they’re still good “because they are yours.”

When she’s older, I want her to remember these moments. Not what I bought her, not what size house we lived in, or the cars we drove. I want her to remember that tomatoes from the garden can brighten a day.  Running barefoot through the rows are where truth and happiness collide. I want her to remember these moments, chipmunk stuffed tomato cheeks, eyes closed as she takes it in, enjoying the simple pleasures of life.

I want her to remember that no amount of money can buy a life of appreciation. True appreciation for life only comes from the depths. You have to be in the thick of it, in the darkest, hardest, truest, most real and at times, nastiest parts of life, to be able to step back and let a summer tomato transform your day.  That is real living.  Our life is so hard on this farm. But Ill be damned if she doesn’t make me want to do it all over again and again as she reminds me of the “why” time and time again.

I took my post about JC Lewis Ford in Savannah down. Not because I didn’t have a horrible experience but because JC Lewis learned a hard lesson today about the power of social media. And honestly I have no one to thank, other than the support from all of you.

I didn’t think we were going to make traction at all with being righted by the dealership. I was sharing, as I often do, about yet another challenge we were facing. But thanks to all of you and the power in numbers, we, James and Myself and the General Manager, came to a reasonable resolution.  And although we came to a resolution, we will not do business with them again for fear of the same thing happening again.

I took my post down because I’m ready to move forward and I know, the dealership is too.  Time will tell if they uphold their end of the most recent agreement, but I will say with pretty good certainty, they don’t want publicity like what they got over the last almost 24 hours.  I’m hoping that will be enough for them to follow through.

If you missed the drama, I can promise, if I know anything about life, there will be more drama again some day for me to share.  But for now, we’re moving onward and upward.

Functioning without a second farm vehicle will be hard, since we sold an older vehicle we had to help make payments toward the vehicle JC Lewis just bought back. But we’ve done harder things before and we will take our time and be choosy about who we work with this time.

I hope in the future though, if I’m posting about a car dealership, it’s because they went above and beyond to work with us and help us so that we can continue to get food to our community in the most ethical ways. I hope some day im posting about a dealership who saw our true value and valued working with us.

Thank you all for the support. It absolutely wouldn’t have come to this outcome, without you all.

I’m not great at remembering dates, anniversaries or birthdays. If you recall, I completely forgot my own husbands birthday this past November.  Today, Ryan told me that it was his 1 year anniversary of working on the farm!  I’m so glad he was tracking because he deserves to be celebrated!

Ryan started with us as a Garden Assistant. He would come in and water and run irrigation, fertilize and help with planting schedules and seed starting. Over the last year, he has morphed into one of the biggest reasons why our gardens are growing as successfully as they are!  He is all of those things he started as and more now!  He is an expert direct seeder, who plants radishes and carrot seeds by hand, in straight lines of perfection with near flawless germination and growth.  He tracks fertilizing schedules, planting needs and successions. He prunes tomatoes and picks for market too. And on top of all of that, he drives for us to the butcher for meat pick ups, delivers our Lowcountry Farm Boxes and delivers to our restaurant partners and he’s even stepping in and helping with a market tomorrow in HHI.

He’s passionate about BBQ and making his own hot sauce and pickles, loves gardening and companion planting and he’s just an overall great guy.  He takes great pride in his work on the farm and it shows.

We’re so lucky to have him apart of the farm family!  Happy Farm-iversary, Ryan!  Go meet Ryan tomorrow at the @hhicommunitymarket, show him lots of love and maybe we can convince him that the Saturday market will be his new favorite gig on the farm!

One thing people are always asking is how are our zinnias so tall with such strong stems?!

1. Do the wiggle test when cutting. Only cut the sturdy stems!
2. Don’t be afraid to cut super low even if it means cutting future potential blooms. Hard pruning helps zinnias thrive!
3. Cut your losses. Go through your flowers and cut the blooms that are less than perfect, too short or too far gone so the plant can put its energy into new, taller, better blooms!

I met Miss Pat a few years ago when we first moved to the big farm. She had been drawn in by the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand. It was right around Thanksgiving and she asked what meat we had for sale. I told her we had pork, chicken and duck. Her eyes perked right up at the duck. But when I told her how much it was, she said, “oh I know it’s worth it and I’d love it. But I can’t afford that. Thank you anyway though.” I told her that if I sold all of the ducks I had for Thanksgiving, I’d save her a duck from our Christmas batch. Sure enough, we sold out and I set a Christmas duck aside for her, on the house.

Over the years we’ve become good neighbors. James used to work on her car when she was having trouble until she was able to get a new car.  Folks would sometimes send us cash for Miss Pat and we’d use it to help pay for the parts her car needed. She would come up to the farm, stop at my office and check on me. And of course, we keep her well fed at the produce stand.  Today we got to catch up at the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand when she stopped by before church looking lovely as ever.

 Over the years, I’ve cherished building our friendship. And I’m proud to be able to help a neighbor like Miss Pat. She inspires me to keep going with her love, support and gratitude for what we’re doing.

Miss Pat will be the first to tell me, “now look, I took food but I couldn’t leave anything this time.” I always tell her, it doesn’t matter to me, that’s not what is important to me.  Being able to provide her with real, organic, fresh food is what matters.

Most people stop and I never get to meet them.  But I’m so grateful that the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand brought me Miss Pat and its mission has allowed me to continue our friendship of giving over the years.

The stand is fully stocked today. Please come TAKE WHAT YOU NEED & PAY WHAT YOU CAN. And if you’re able, please leave the suggested price (there is a scale and a price list for most items) or more, if you’re able. Doing that, helps us continue with our mission to help support our neighbors, just like Miss Pat.

When I ask my mom if she thinks I’ll get bad paybacks from Ellie for how I was as a teenager to she and my dad… she just says, “buckle up buttercup!” with a big grin. 😂 we’re screwed 😂 but at least maybe my mom will get a kick out of it

Everyone always asks, “but what about bugs?!? How do you manage them?”

Picking tomatoes when they are just starting to ripen is one way we make our big heirloom varieties less interesting to insects.  By doing this, it prevents bugs from wreaking havoc on them as they ripen and it even prevents splitting, which happens often because we get a lot of rain in our climate.

We don’t do this quite as aggressively with our cherry tomato varieties. But we still pick them slightly underripe to help with shelf life to ensure when our tomatoes get to our customers, they are at their peak flavor profile and will last for days.

Believe it or not, by mid July, tomato season will be over here for our first set of plants. It’s too hot for the plants to set fruit and the wet wet summer will have brought lots of bacteria and fungus along with all the insects. So we enjoy them while we can!  Lucky for us though, we will get a second crop of tomatoes, if we can control seedling health through the heat, with a October and November harvest with seedlings we will plant in July/August!

If you’re seeing leaves that are starting to look like lace, army worms could be the culprit!

If you are like us and farm without harmful chemicals, there isn’t much you can do once you start to see an infestation, especially on a large scale with thousands of plants.  There are certainly some sprays you can try that are “organic”, but for us, we also like to attack the problem head on with some good old fashioned elbow grease smooshing.  This is easy to do while we’re out pruning and picking.

This is part of why we prune so aggressively. If you allow your plant to bush out, you are putting it at greater risks of pest issues. Not everyone’s climate is as hard to grow in, as ours, when it comes to tomatoes grown without chemicals. But we sure give it our best shot!  And although we certainly see pest issues, we see a greater benefit to growing this way, than not.
If you love growing cute vegetables but also love nearly dying in the summer heat, half way through a 100’ row, Fairytale Eggplants are for you.

In 2022 I almost bought a slaughterhouse. I was talking with investors, potential partners, the bank, financial advisors and agriculture business consultants. I had inspectors go out and look at it with me.  I was so close to doing it. But there was something in me that was still so far away.  Not buying a slaughter facility is probably the best business choice I could’ve made in 2022.  But I still think about it.

In 2022 we spent just shy of $50,000 in butchering (processing) fees.  Our closest USDA processor that does beef, poultry and pork is 3 hours, one way, away.  That $50,000 doesn’t include the hauling fees paid to our driver, the fuel, the truck maintenance, trailers and repairs on our trailers, it’s just what we pay the butcher.  It doesn’t even include the $5,000 in plastic cages sitting on that trailer each trip.  We sat down and crunched the numbers, many times over. And financially it made sense if we could open our own facility nearby. Remove the hours of hauling fees, fuel & wear and tear, not to mention always get back the product that we are proud to have our label on.  And even if financially, in the long run, it would be better, I still couldn’t commit.

On a farm tour this weekend, someone asked me what my goals are 5 years from now. They cited my ambition & drive & excitement to see me grow more. I told them, that I was sorry to disappoint but my goal right now is to ride the waves from the storm we’re facing and maybe when the calm hits, bask in it for a moment.  I have no big goals right now, I told them. My goal is to do exactly what we’re doing, but do it better, every time. Not bigger, right now, just better.

In 2023, better doesn’t look like a slaughter facility for me. We could argue it would be better, in many ways. But the better I’m seeking right now, is better balance.  I want better for myself and my family but better for my staff too.  I want better presence, from me to my family and me to my staff. I want to be a better entrepreneur, leader, wife, mom, neighbor & farmer.

5 years ago this October we started selling publicly. In our first year, we grossed what we do now in a month.  Grown, we have. 2023 we get better at it.

Have you ever been to a chicken party!?

Full disclosure… we’ve lost about 20 chickens in the last 3 days to hawks in broad daylight with a lot of activity around their current section forest.  We started with 700 chickens out in the woods and we’re down to 680.  We have them in an area of woods that has a great open area but it’s proven to be the perfect swooping spot for hawks.  The dogs are hot and hanging in the shade during the day and are only seeing the hawks AFTER the kill.  We’ve raised our chickens like this for almost 4 years now without such staggering losses. We were kind of at a loss as to what to do because even with moving the chickens, we were still afraid the hawk would continue to find them because he was on to them. So we devised another plan. We threw them a party in the woods with balloons and shiny streamers and it’s working!

The last 24 hours have resulted in no more attacks. And the hawk has been hanging nearby keeping close tabs on things. But this party is far too lively for him!

Cheers to inexpensive solutions to expensive problems and learning to farm alongside of the wildlife and not against them!

The things farmers let their kids do just to get the work done! 😂

Honestly though, we wouldn’t have it any other way.  And I sure would rather be picking tomatoes with her doing this instead of being behind a screen!  And I didn’t even have to spend money on a slip and slide 😂

We stopped letting people come stay at the farm who have dogs. We allowed dogs, for years until we finally decided that it just wasn’t worth it any more.

Agritoursim was a huge part of what we did. We had become so busy that we used to employ someone full time just to manage bookings, phone calls, greeting and answering questions and tending to guests.  But when the dogs stopped, so did many of the bookings.  We had been having a lot of other guest issues too. And the dogs, coupled with other guest issues we’d been having, drove us to pull one of our Air BnBs and take a break from another.

But the only constant is change.  It was scary at first, losing revenue that we had depended on for so long, that we were used to seeing.  We shifted employee responsibilities, adjusted our mindset and kept grinding, focusing on all the things we could control, focusing again, on better, not bigger (it’s my 2023 theme if you haven’t noticed yet).

With my brain space shifted away from guest issues, I’ve been able to focus more on growing food and providing for our community (our goal all along) and guiding my staff to do just that, to the best of our ability.  And we sure have.

This summer season so far has been our most productive one yet, cranking out hundreds of pounds of veggies at every harvest, focusing on our livestock, creating new garden spaces and thinning the forests for better Silvopasture sections. We’re not flawless in execution.  Our to do list is still a mile long at the end of every day but we are focused. I am more present for Ellie during the day and in the evenings & I spend more time out in the fields working than putting out fires. And honestly, as much as we loved having a farm filled with guests walking around & learning about what we do, it’s so much more pleasant on the farm without the constant stress of a farm full of guests & their dogs not following directions or heeding warnings.

Agirtourism helped fund our farm, there’s no question about that. But we, along with our staff got us here and will continue forward!

Come to Hilton Head Farmers Market tomorrow from 9am to 1pm and help support our goal, of providing your family with amazing food!

It’s been such a rainy spring!

Seeking refuge in the trees with the Forest Birds!
It’s been a very rainy spring and start to summer on the farm!  Luckily, the way we raise our livestock and the breeds we choose, allow them to thrive even in less than ideal conditions!

I last minute had to fly home to NJ yesterday morning to help my family with something. I’ll be honest, it was a really great feeling to be able to call Phoebe the farm manager on Thursday night and say, “if I caught a flight out of here tonight or first thing in the morning, you feel like you could hold it down?” And of course, her answer was, “yes!” Not only that but Victoria and Joseph both came in and worked yesterday on their day off to also hold things down as well. And Beth who works for me, doing mostly driving and markets also came in to help prep for markets. AND prep they did!  Our farm wouldn’t be what it is without our amazing team who continues to show up for us AND our customers every day!

I fly home tomorrow evening, but you’ll get to see James (a very rare sighting!) and Phoebe at the Forsyth Farmers Market tomorrow from 9am to 1pm!

The team harvested HUNDREDS of pounds of cucumbers, zucchini, tomatoes, squash, eggplant and more!  We’ll also have lots of flowers as well! And of course, pork, chicken, beef AND eggs!  Oh!  And we’ll even have the first of the chanterelles!

Please stop by and show us some love and support and get some of the best food grown in the lowcountry to feed your family with!

I give up on trying to keep the hog waters clean 🤷🏽‍♀️ a losing battle I’ve been fighting for years because someone always wants to wash their a$$ in the troughs 😭 even when there’s plenty of butt washing water around!

HAPPY FATHERS DAY!  James is so happy I’m home to help him again on the farm and spend Father’s Day with he and Ellie!  We spent the morning stocking the stand together and enjoying a cup coffee. I’m so grateful I could go help my family but I’m definitely happy to be home!

The biggest question I get about the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand is “do you actually make money?” The answer is “that isn’t really the point.”

The actual goal of the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand is to give every person in our community access to real, organically grown food. And that means that sometimes people can’t pay our retail prices but that’s exactly what the stand is for.

My goal each week has always been to take 10% of our total gross vegetable revenue and put it back on the stand in goods. Sometimes that looks like $40. But sometimes is looks like $400 or more.  We always hope to recuperate the funds for the goods we put out but that is never the goal. We do hope though that those able to pay, use our suggested retail price board and scale to pay retail price or slightly more to help make up for those in our community facing the very real problem of food insecurity.  But this is why we set an attainable goal for ourselves for what we can give back.  We prefer to do it this way instead of donating to a food bank because this is yet another place, another access point for people to get food. And that’s the goal.

This program only works because we all work together. Myself the farmer, the local community of those able to pay who come out to support, supporters from afar who contribute financially through our website and of course those in our community facing food insecurity.

If you are a local farmer thinking that this is a great idea for revenue, you’re wrong. But if you are thinking this is a great way to support your community through your work, you’re absolutely right. Set a goal like we have of 10% in veggie sales (or another figure) to go back in goods (remember we have many revenue streams on our farm. So 10% of veggie sales is an attainable goal for us without going broke trying to help). You’ll meet people in your community you never would have without the stand and you’ll be helping so many you would’ve never realized needed help without it.

Regenerative farming works by helping all of natures cycles work together!  This includes implementing animal rotation into gardens, composting from food production and soil building and carbon sequestration through no till practices.

Don’t just buy organic food, buy food that’s grown organically, locally and also grown using the most thoughtful environmental processes along the way!  Find a local farmer near you today putting in the effort and support them!

I haven’t been writing lately, I talked about it briefly a while ago. My mind is preoccupied. I told a friend today when they asked how I was coping, that I really wasn’t. “All the things that used to bring me joy, that would quiet my mind, bring an aching silence I now fill.” I fill it with rehearsed verses in my head of the things I’ll say if I end up having to defend myself and all we’ve built.  I try to go through my days pretending looming things aren’t eating away at me, but they are.  I pick in the gardens, thoughts creep in and I find myself talking to myself, practicing what I’ll say.  I cut flowers.  I lay compost. I feed livestock. I sow seeds. It’s all the same, the thoughts darken even the sunniest of days .  Moments where I used to reflect and find myself journaling in my head, so I could publicly journal later are now filled with heart racing anxiety. The longer the time passes, the worse it becomes. And the hardest part for me, I can’t talk about it, even worse, I can’t write about it.  She told me to try as hard as I can to find the joy in the quiet again, when thoughts creep, immediately remember what I’m grateful for, repeat it in my head.

Tonight 530 came, all the staff had left and it was dead quiet on the farm. I dreaded the remaining hours in the day.  I thought of how Ellie would want me to hang out and watch her in the pond. Sitting there, watching her, my thoughts taking over, was sure to drive me mad.  To my surprise, I walked out of the office and she was standing there with Willow wanting me to saddle her up.  It was everything I needed, spending time with her, watching her, coaching her.  It gave me quiet and gave me purpose I’d been needing.

After a while, she asked to ride bareback so i pulled the saddle off. I dared her to take the bridle off too.  She shimmied up from the fence and on her own, I coached her on how to pull the bridle off while she was still on her horse. She dropped it outside of the rails, smiled at me and said, “and what if I fall?” She already knew the answer, she’d get back up.  But she didn’t fall, she flew. And for that hour or so she rode, I felt like myself again. I felt like I could write.

Everyone always asks if Ellie does chores.  She actually has a morning chore routine that she completes every day before school work starts!  She usually finishes this chore list before I’ve even come outside for the day.

Her morning chore routine is always feeding her dogs who get the raw chicken dog food we sell from our forest chickens raised right here on the farm, going down and feeding the egg laying hens and rotating her horse to the pasture she’s grazing on for that day.  If we’re not moving the horse, she gives her hay and alfalfa mash for the day. Then she grabs something to eat and starts school work with her tutor who comes to the farm.

Around lunch time she goes back down to the layers and feeds them their lunch. We don’t free feed any of our livestock so the chickens get breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Later in the afternoons she’ll help with whatever odd jobs we need her help with. And at night before bed she always helps with moving her horse back, giving her hay and fresh water and putting the dogs up into the spots they keep watch over, at night.

We try to have Ellie help with things she enjoys, most of the time. We sure don’t want her to hate living on a farm because she always feels like she’s constantly working. But starting her young with helping, has made it so that at this age, she’s much more prepared to help.  And giving her the freedom to try methods and ways of doing things that work for her helps too. She’s come up with her chore systems and has asked for things she needs along the way to make it easier for her. Like 2 small buckets for her horse water instead of a big bucket, barrels down at the egg layers instead of worrying about carting feed etc.

It’s been a joy raising Ellie from a newborn on the farm to this and watching how she has grown and matured and become more and more helpful and willing over the years.

This is another task Ellie likes to help with. We let her use the skid steer so she can easily put feed into the bucket and bring it down from feed storage and then get it over the fencing without having to drag it over or take fencing down.  Plus what 8 year old doesn’t want an excuse to drive around a skid steer?!

We don’t free feed our chickens. Instead we feed them breakfast, lunch and dinner to encourage more foraging and movement throughout their rotational sections. We also don’t feed in feeders. We spread feed out in places in the pastures where we want their impact on the soil. They scratch around in different areas, crimping grasses and cover crop and leaving their manure as fertilizer.  Each time we can choose a new area to move them through for their impact.  If there’s a particularly over grown area, we can get it back under control by feeding them over it. If there’s an area we don’t want their impact heavily on, we can avoid it by not feeding over it.  This helps our forests and pastures come back healthier each and every time.

Chanterelle Season is here!

With all the rain this spring Chanterells showed up mighty early, then took a week or so off when it dried up. But the recent heat and wet weather has them popping off again!

By farming amongst our forests, instead of clear cutting for pastures, we’re able to enjoy all the gifts that Mother Nature bestows upon us, like chanterelle mushrooms, a culinary favorite!

Sautéed in some butter, then poured over some of our chicken thighs, is my favorite way to enjoy them!
Checking on one of our groups of pigs foraging in a section we recently did chop and drop in to open up the forest canopy.

It started happening the minute we started marketing our farm, which was actually quite a while before we even sold our first product.  People would reach out and ask “how we do this and how we do that.” At that time I was already sharing a lot of free content on my social media channels, where if they just dug a little deeper, they most likely find the answer.  Sometimes I’d field the questions in between caring for our own farm which at the time was very small, volunteering at other farms to learn, paying experts for their advice and even working part time at other farms while still holding a full time off farm job. Oh did I mention I was a brand new mom at the time too?  I’d entertain the questions and then eventually get frustrated, feeling like, “I’m out here busting my butt to build my business, paying other people for advice and knowledge and I’m tired of giving all my hard earned experience and knowledge for free.” So I started charging for consultations. The minute I’d share that I offer consultations for a fee, 9/10 times the questions would stop and the person would disappear or worse, bad mouth me publicly for not sharing my knowledge freely (free consumable content apparently wasn’t enough).

Almost 9 years later from the start and 5 years this fall into growing our Ag business and the trend has never stopped. “We just bought land and are trying to make it work and be successful, how do you do it?”

There’s no secret formula. What works for me, doesn’t work for everyone else. Every ag business is as unique as the land it’s on.  And while it may look like on social media, we are “successful,” success in and of itself is different for each person.

But what I will say is that a team, a strong team who stands behind you and beside you or in front of you when you need it and believes in what you do, will make or break you.  Scaling our business didn’t happen on our own. It happened because of them and others who have come and gone over the years. Find your team, pay them all you can afford to, sacrifice your own luxuries to help them achieve and they will help you grow.  We’re grateful for our team every single day.

It’s been wildly hot, but some how were still standing, cranking out produce, caring for our livestock and continually planting!  Just today even we transplanted more cucumbers and winter squash!  Tomorrow more zucchini and summer squash are on the list and a bunch of seeds are ready to be started in the greenhouse.

The next 700 of the 4,000 meat chickens for 2023 move out to forests this week, cows left for breeding and in just a week or so, more pigs go for processing and the next batch of meat chickens will be finished their time on the farm.  And Thursday I head to pick up a new, bigger greenhouse!

Every day I think about quitting at least once. It’s hot and hard. I can’t imagine what my staff feels, this isn’t even their dream. But we keep pushing through, surviving on lemon lime Gatorade, Body Armor and OUTLAST fruit popsicles.  We don’t keep a seasonal staff, so instead we just stay busy all year round, when lots of other farms take it easier in July and August down here because it’s so hard to grow through the heat.  But each day, the gardens surprise me with their resilience and the livestock use their instincts to cope and the staff uses their sense of humor to make it through.

One of the greatest unexpected joys of my adulthood has been getting to know my mom. We all changed the day my dad died over 11 years ago. My relationship with my mom changed.  I grew up and then I watched her grow.

She’s seen the stretching stages of growth, reaching up and around what was blocking her sunlight, trying to find her light again.  It took her time for her roots to settle into the earth and establish, reaching to the depths for the nutrients, trying to right herself. I’ve seen her storms come, threatening to knock her from what she’d worked to establish. And I’ve watched drought come to suck her spirit dry and snuff her flame.  And I’ve watched moments like this, the truest matriarch, in her element when she’s surrounded by family, feeding her soul.

There is always beauty in the pain. Her beauty throughout her life and even through her painful childhood has been her journey and her unwavering strength, finding herself again and continuing to work to forgive her past regrets and forge positive experiences for her future.  Her beauty has been growing her relationship with her grandchildren and her grown children. Allowing me to know a woman, I would’ve never realized existed all those years ago, when I fought against her, kicking and screaming, as she fought to keep me alive and fighting the torments of my own mind.

The older I grow, the more mature I become, the more I see her battle scars. Her battle scars, even the ones that I gave her, especially through my teenage years.  I look back and wonder how we got here, how we survived.  I marvel at a mothers love of their child, that runs deeply through the soul, a constant forgiveness, even forgiveness of the most hateful things I said, a young and immature girl, who thought way back then even, that I knew all the things, had it all figured out.  I marvel at her forgiveness of all the pain she’s seen through her life and her strength to continue after the dust has settled.

The older I grow, the more I mature I become, the more her love and forgiveness and strength humbled me.  We miss my dad everyday.  But I’m certain this, our growth and love, has been his lesson to us.

Ellie and her first horse Ruby, November 2016 at our first farm. Ellie was only 1.5 years old!  She affectionately referred to Ruby as Ru Ru and all horses for that matter for the longest time. Ruby was a great horse and still lives nearby in GA.

I’ve been getting A LOT of messages asking what you should plant this time of year, where to order seeds from and all things fall.  Hope this helps answer some questions!  We’re in zone 8b near Savannah, GA.

We are not affiliated with @johnnys_seeds but we do buy 99.9% of our seeds from them. As a commercial grower, we count on their consistency, availability and customer support. But there’s plenty of places you can buy seeds from or of course, save your own.  We prefer to leave the seed saving, on this scale up to the experts and we order large quantities a few times per year.

There are so many reasons why we choose to raise our meat chickens in this manner. But one of my favorite parts over the years has been watching them transform our forests, alongside of our other livestock, into beautiful, usable spaces where we can feed our community while keeping trees in place for our native animals and birds and pollinators.

Freedom rangers are motivated foragers unlike Cornish cross chickens. They’ll travel through the forests and work in the sections, slowly transforming spaces, crimping ground cover, fertilizing, controlling pests and leaving our Silvopastures in beautiful condition for the next round of rest and rotation.

We have lots more videos on how we raise our chickens in this manner so if you have questions, chances are it’s answered in more videos on our page. And if you’re looking to deep dive further to implement this on your farm, we’re always available for one on one consultations (in person or through zoom) or through a farm tour.  Send us a message for rates and to deep dive with us to learn more.

The first summer we were together was the best summer of my life. I had been chasing my summers in Italy for years.  Italy, each summer I’d spent there since turning 18, left me feeling alive. A feeling that slowly dissipated in the months following my return. I’d chase it in the states, trying to find the excitement, looking in all the wrong places. I craved the late nights, the limoncello, the foreignness of it all of it all. My comfort zone of the states would not facilitate the kind of distraction I needed. I’d go back to the same destructive behaviors and everything would always turn out the same.  They were always the same, the spiraling was always the same and I’d stay far longer than anyone ever should.

I sold everything for the last time and this time instead of jetting out of the country, I moved into an RV park.  It was a lifestyle unlike any i had ever experienced and the people, my neighbors, were as foreign to me, as they came. And as it turns out, a boy from South Georgia, with a beer can in a paper bag, standing over a burn barrel, to this Jersey Girl was about as foreign as it gets and it’s all I really needed.

We’ve had good summers since then. We had the first summer with our daughter, summers building our farms, the summer we sold the first farm and bought the big one. And we had summers like this. A summer where we’ve reclaimed some peace in our life, reclaimed some time. And after years of hustling, took some time to step back and remember what started it all. Dirt roads and canning tomatoes, fishing in all the secret spots, sunsets at the beach and Coors Light in coozies.

The weeds have taken over the gardens, the grass is long, the sign that marks the farm at the entrance is barely recognizable from the summer growth and let’s not even talk about the house or the laundry situation. But none of it really matters, because this July, we got back to what started it all for us all those years ago.  Someone asked me today, what my perfect day with my family looks like. It looks like this, it looks like this July.  It looks like letting some things go to get some of the things back. A balancing act I’m forever chasing, with him by my side.

We use GSD on our farm. They serve multiple purposes with our livestock.

✔️Predator control at night and during the day (they don’t just bark, they kill)
✔️ Helping us to round up rogue chickens and holding them without harming them for us to come and grab them
✔️ Protecting us from human intruders
✔️ One of the dogs in particular is great at killing rats and mice in our feed barn AND alerting to snakes

But their favorite job on the farm that they only get to do once in while…

✔️ Putting pigs back into their fencing if we have an electric fence shortage

About a month ago we had two large pigs get out because we had a tree fall on fencing and we didn’t see it yet. The pigs were wandering down towards our gardens and before I even realized what was happening, two of our GSDs were on their tails and had them back into their forest sections before I could even grab the 4-wheeler to help.

Usually the dogs work so fast, I can’t even capture it. But this video in particular, I lucked out when we saw this piglet had gotten out. I was in the truck on the trail and Johnny worked through the woods to put that piglet back with its mama who didn’t even realize he was gone 😂

All of our dogs have been rescues. All of our dogs came with high prey drives and killed many many chickens before we were able to break them of that and harness their desire to work.  Our farm wouldn’t function without our dogs!  These dogs have been worth all of the work we put in with them to have them be apart of the success of our farm!

If there’s anything I’ve learned over the years, it’s that I have learned A LOT. From selecting our land to starting our farm business to building infrastructure to marketing our products to leading a team of employees and scaling our farm, the list goes on and on.  And if I’ve learned anything over the last year especially, it’s that a lot of people want to learn about what we do specifically and how to make it work for them.

And although our consultation program is very successful (through both zoom and in person consultations), we know that financially, our private consultations are not always attainable for everyone.

Over the next few months, we’ll be working on finally launching an education series of webinars (something I’ve wanted to do for a long time but just never made the time). But I’m finally doing it!

Our education webinar programs will be hour long live sessions, with myself and a capped number of attendees where virtually we will cover tons of topics.  Everything from selecting your farm land to learning your markets to the finances of farming and everyone’s favorite, how to raise forest chickens, you will be able to join us to start your venture or learn new things to implement on your farm!

Class sizes will be limited to make sure that I am able to answer questions and make the experience as valuable as possible for everyone.

If you want to be the first to know when classes launch, DM us your email and we will add you to our email list to make sure that you are the first to know!

There will be a “Series Option” where you can sign up for the series for a discounted rate or of course an option to just sign up for just the webinar you’re most interested in!

We’ll look for your email address and get you added so you can start growing!

Ellie has been helping me in the gardens since she was born. I have so many fond memories of her just digging in the dirt next to me. She’s also been helping me seed start since she was big enough to express interest in helping.

Often times she’d mess up my progress, I’d have to go back behind her and start all over again or once she’d moved on to the next thing. But I knew some day it would get us to the point where she’d be able to complete a task unassisted and complete it well. That meant letting go of my expectations, never pressuring her to help and allowing her to help in the way that was interesting to her.  If it meant getting covered in mud for 7 minutes and then asking for a snack and to go play on her swing, then that’s what we did. I’d just go back and finish later.

Now at 8 years old, Ellie is super capable at so many tasks on the farm. One of which is soil blocking and being more precise about it than even some of my staff 😂.

We do a 2 part @foxfarmsoilandfertilizer garden soil blend that we buy, by the pallet and a 1 part vermiculite mixture.  We like our soil soupy and wet for our blocks. We use a @johnnys_seeds 4 block soil blocker or the 20 cell soil blocker and this is how every plant is started on our farm!  No plastic cells, no unnecessary waste, just soil.

I have loved including my daughter in our farm life as she has grown up. And it’s certainly a prideful moment when you watch her complete soil block trays, perfectly, on her own, all because she loves to help and be apart of the team.

For the longest time I have been a leader, mentor and educator.  My roots in teaching goes back to when I was a young teenager, giving horseback riding lessons to fund my own horse habit.  When I began my professional career, I was always a mentor, helping new employees, later moving into leadership and continuing to lead as my career advanced.  But eventually all of that changed when I started farming.

Now almost 9 years into growing food for ourselves and 5 years into commercially selling, I have had to devote almost all of my time to teaching myself, focusing hard on developing myself and our business.  In 5 years time we have taken a 2 acre farm and grown it to the 40 acre, regenerative farm we are today.  We have built our farms both from scratch completely, with nothing but culverts and overgrown forests in place when we bought our properties.  We did everything you see today without start up cash, operating loans or investors. But not only have we built the land but we have scaled our business from grossing 4 figures in revenue yearly to where we are now.

But in all of that focus, the desire to help others succeed, mentor them and teach them, has never left me. I am finally ready to start diving in with you all and devoting more of my time to teaching and watching you all succeed and build your agriculture businesses, homesteads or simply growing better in your home gardens.

I am so excited to be offering webinars in the coming months to help you all achieve your goals.  I think the most beautiful thing about working with the land is that there are so many ways to do one thing and still achieve the vision.  My goal is to help you harness the techniques I use and apply them to your own piece of land, big or small, in whatever ways feel right to you.  Whether or not you're in my state, country or climate, we can all learn from each other to apply knowledge to our own situations.  I'm looking forward to sharing my knowledge with you.

If you’re interested in learning more, send us your email in a direct message and we’ll make sure you’re first to know as webinars start to roll out!

Marissa and Ellie for @duluthtradingcompany

Leslie, Ellie’s teacher who comes to the farm to homeschool Ellie so I can work, said to me yesterday, “you have really become the fun mom.” I said, “shhhhh, please don’t start rumors like that.” Leslie laughed, “I just think you’re doing so great with spending time with her. Remember when you told me you were “the mean mom?”

I don’t think I’ve become the fun mom, I think she was always inside of me.  But I had to uncover her, dig down deeply through the layers of whatever it was that I had been holding onto, blocking me from expressing truly, the love I have for my daughter.  I felt a lump in my throat for the first time regarding Ellie maybe a year ago.  Like worry creeping in, an innate desire to protect her & take out anything that threatened her.  A feeling for the first time, that if i lost her, I’d lose all of myself. I’d be lying if I had said I had felt it many times for my child.  I love Ellie & I always have, but there was something missing in me, something just not quite right instinctually, from her birth.  I noticed it’s absence, acknowledged it, told it, “I didn’t know how to fix you.” So I was the best I knew to be, trying to connect, trying to feel the instinctual pull, loving all the while but distant still.

I found myself finally though, when that lump creeped in. For the first time ever, I started checking on her at night as she sleeps and I can’t because my mind is racing.  I like to make sure she’s still there now, I like to watch her sleepy breaths.  I don’t think I work less these days.  I certainly don’t involve her more than before, she’s always been by my side. I have just learned how to connect to her. The fun mom is my energy shift, connection, the visible care I give now, the worry & instinct toward her I have found.

I’m not ashamed to admit I struggled, isn’t that what life is?  Riding the waves of change, peaks & valleys, acknowledging shifts, forgiving, doing better?  Maybe it’s age, maybe it’s maturity or maybe it’s forgiveness to myself after years of trying to heal from the mental chaos that was my youth and early adulthood.

You can call me the fun mom, now. Just don’t say it too loud. I have a reputation to uphold.

I have just learned how to connect to her. The fun mom is my energy shift, connection, the visible care I give now, the worry & instinct toward her I have found.

I’m not ashamed to admit I struggled, isn’t that what life is?  Riding the waves of change, peaks & valleys, acknowledging shifts, forgiving, doing better?  Maybe it’s age, maybe it’s maturity or maybe it’s forgiveness to myself after years of trying to heal from the mental chaos that was my youth and early adulthood.

You can call me the fun mom, now. Just don’t say it too loud. I have a reputation to uphold.
Don’t worry though folks!  We have a whole team of people double checking for worms for you before we send to market!  And guess what?  I’m not one of them 😂! At least we know it’s “organic!”

To piggy back a little more on yesterdays post about egg chickens, check out this reel about the avian reproductive system!

Right now, a lot of you are experiencing decreased egg production. This is typical for this time of year. Decreased sunlight (shorter days) and molting season all contribute to this.  Don’t panic. Help your chickens through by increasing protein and probiotics and they will recover more quickly from molting.

And if youre a shopper, you will see less eggs at market.  Yes, eggs raised with natures cycles are seasonal. Don’t forget, you can always stock up next year and water glass them or even freeze them to make sure you’re getting nutrient dense eggs through the winter without having to shop at the grocery store. 

As a producer, you can also use artificial lights in your coops to continue to increase daylight. We do not do this however because we feel like with all things in nature, rest and recovery is necessary. It helps our chickens live longer, healthier lives and supports a more natural and seasonal food system that we should all get used to supporting.
Out in the forests with the Freedom Rangers chatting all things forest chickens!

Training Tips from Farmer Ellie!

Not only is Ellie great with her chickens and her horse, but she also has a very special relationship with one of our working dogs that she named Bolt.  One day I looked up and Bolt was riding around on the quad with her. I asked how she got her to do it and this is what she told me!

Looking forward to see what other animals she bonds with as she gets older!

Ellie has been on vacation since Thursday away from the farm. Can you tell I’m missing seeing the nonsense she and the dogs get into?!

I’ve been in charge of feeding the dogs, belly rubs, treats, more belly rubs and lots of reminding Bolt that her mommy will be back soon to do ridiculous things with her.  And as usual, in the meantime, Bolt, Johnny and Moose have been doing a great job at night watching over the livestock and Ellie’s group of “misfit” chickens that live up by the front garden while patiently waiting for Ellie’s return.

You never know what gifts the forests will surprise us with as it comes back to life after livestock rotations, like this Lions Mane Mushroom I found!

It’s been a beautiful journey to watch our livestock naturally thin our forests over the last almost 4 years. It’s been even more beautiful seeing the signs of a greater more functioning system coming back in afterward, like native forage plants and even fungi. Things like this, show us, although we’ve chosen the longer path as opposed to machinery coming in to thin, we are definitely on the right path!

We have still been reaping the benefits from the Great Fish Planting in Summer 2022!  From food compost to fish waste to manure compost and more, our no till gardens have seen so many amendments that have continued to slowly break down over time and help build a biodiverse ecosystem in our permanent beds.

If this is something you want to try, we recommend really good, tall, small gauge fencing around your gardens to keep wildlife out. We also always have our dogs out patrolling and keeping problem predators away and out of our gardens too.  It’s been about a year since our last fish planting and our gardens are teaming with earthworms, microbes and beneficial bacteria helping to facilitate the growth of the veggies we sell!

Think outside of the box, forget the naysayers and try something different. You won’t regret it and you’ll ALWAYS learn something!

Today one of our hatcheries for our baby chicks that we raise for meat, reached out to me to let me know that, the company they ship their chicks through, that I had already paid for our last batch of chicks, had without warning suddenly closed their doors.  The hatchery told me that if I wanted to get my shipment I had to pay again.  The phone number for the original company had been turned off, emails were bouncing back and there was no way to get in touch.  This is a company I have been working with for the last 8 years and had nothing but great experiences with up until today. I was in shock.

I fought as hard as I could with the hatchery, explaining that I paid, a payment the hatchery was never sent apparently, back in July. I paid just shy of $2,000 for the September birds and unfortunately need them for our customers as we will never be able to fulfill our Farm Boxes or have product for market for the beginning of 2024 without those chickens.  The hatchery wouldn't budge. They said, if I wanted the chickens, I’d pay again, simple as that. So I forked over the funds, yet again.  I've taken all the steps I could so far to try to recover the initial payment but time will tell.

It's truly always something with running a small business.  And often times with farming, it honestly feels harder most days. If it's not mother nature, it's another challenge just waiting in the wings, ready to take you out.  So we could truly use the support at market tomorrow and every weekend.  Your support at market each week helps us run our business.  Your support is the reason why I had emergency funds tucked away.  But your support is so much more than that.

Yes, you pay an elevated price for our chicken or any of our products than you pay from conventionally raised food.  But I can promise you the heart and soul and quality and truth AND nutrients of the product is far beyond anything you could ever get from conventionally raised food.

Please help us keep the dream alive today, tomorrow, far in to the future.  Support us tomorrow at market and support local farms every day.  We need our customers, like our customers, need us & the nutritious food we grow and raise for you.

2023 has been a year different from all of our other years farming.  5 years into business, 2023 has been the year where we have really dug in deeply to the roots that began all of this, feeding our community and we truly have been doing just that.  It’s also been the year I’ve seen the most challenges.  Financial challenges, staffing challenges, challenges with guests visiting the farm, weather challenges, the list goes on and on.  But through all of those challenges, this team right here (missing Ryan and Tatiana) continued to push through. 
Each person on our team has their own special reasons they want to be here, and those reasons are uniquely special to who they are as people.  Our team has the most unique crew, all different walks of life, at all stages in their lives, but we all share a common goal of having a career that makes a difference in our world, some how.

Although 2023 has been hard for me as a business owner, this team has made running the daily operations of the farm a breeze.  Always willing to step up, go above and beyond, stay late or come in early and continue to push through the sweltering, unforgiving summer that we faced.

Because of this team we accomplished so much.  Some of those accomplishments include having our best year so far with our vegetable production, providing to many local restaurants on a weekly basis AND having a strong Saturday Farmer’s Market selection almost every Saturday so far this year.  We’ve expanded our Lowcountry Farm Box subscriber list to more than we’ve ever been able to service, with the team stepping up to prepare orders, pick and prep and deliver boxes on schedule with minimal hiccups every week.  We have been able to stock the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand with more meat, eggs and veggies than ever before helping EVERY ONE in our community have access to organically grown food.  And our livestock health has been better than ever as their consistent attention to detail and care shines through each day making sure problems are addressed immediately.

Thank you, Team, for an amazing 2023 so far and looking forward to much success and accomplishments in the future.  Cheers to cooler days ahead!

We used to have feeders out for our egg chickens. But we noticed a trend in feed consumption, with the feed consumption being much higher than what a chicken actually needed to be healthy and producing. We also were having trouble with them utilizing their full pastures, leaving some of the areas in their pastures untouched, unfertilized and not impacted by their help in creating healthier pastures after they move off.  So we switched things up and started feeding breakfast, lunch and dinner instead, pouring their high protein organic grain right on the areas of pasture that need their impact the most.  After about a year of doing this, we will never go back to filling feeders.

This is a practice we had been utilizing for our meat chickens to help them grow out evenly without gorging on feed and I’m so glad we switched to doing this for our egg chickens too.

The chickens help with eradicating invasive weeds in our pastures through pecking, scratching and fertilizing and they help keep insect populations in check as they move through and rotate pastures make a healthy space for the next species of livestock to follow.

We want to raise THE MOST natural, close to wild product available. To us, that means minimal human intervention, including feed. By not free feeding our livestock, it encourages them to get creative, utilize the spaces they are rotated through for nourishment and leave their impact behind to make our pastures and forests healthier and more fertile than when we began.

This is how we prep for hurricanes on OUR farm. Everyone’s situation is different, everyone’s farm is different. But years of farming through hurricanes have our prepping down to a science that works for us.  And a reel cannot possibly cover everything we do to prep our livestock, but here is a snapshot.  Currently on farm we’re prepping for about 2,000 chickens, 150 pigs, livestock dogs, cattle and gardens, plus infrastructure prep.  Our farm is 20 miles inland from the coast between Savannah GA and Charleston SC. 

The egg chicken’s coops doors will be left open through the storm and the night. This allows them the ability to escape safely if wind or rain threaten the safety of their coop. They will always come back if they have to leave their coops for safety.  We would never want a tree to fall on them and them be trapped or the coop to blow over if it gets that bad and them be stuck inside.

Meat chickens are kept in high elevation wooded areas with lots of low branches for roosting to escape flooding or brush they can huddle under for safety.  Chicks in the brooder have stayed in longer than normal to protect them from the storm.

Cattle are released from small rotational grazing sections to allow them more space to run away if scared or seeking shelters. 

Halters and collars are removed to prevent hang ups on fencing or debris if there is danger causing them to flee.  Instead, small ID tags are braided into tails and manes.

Water is pumped from our irrigation pond into holding totes in case generators are occupied and we need water fast.

All livestock are given access to double the amount of feed and water they normally would have. If we have to put our energy into infrastructure issues, we know what we’ve provided can keep them happy and their bellies full for at least 24 hours.

The pigs who usually get MUCH LESS feed are spoiled during storms to keep them away from getting mischievous and testing fencing that may be down.  They’ll still forage, but they’ll also still be naughty too.  So we like to prevent that desire as much as possible.

We completed the last of our hurricane preps today just before the storm started to roll in!

After years of farming through hurricanes, we have learned it’s always better to be over prepared and overly cautious. For us, we weren’t going to pull water from the irrigation pond and prep to tie down the egg mobiles (our mobile coops for our egg chickens) but after watching the forecast as the storm inched closer, we decided to just go ahead and do it.  Our chickens will have the option of staying in or going out and it will be better if we can just be sure their coops are stable through 100mph wind gusts.

We use totes that we typically pick up bulk grains in or distillers or brewers grain. The color of the water comes from the grain remnants and I can promise, the chickens won’t be complaining if they end up having to drink this water after.  We can easily take a generator down to our pastures, plug in a pump and pump water directly out of these totes, leaving us completely independent from needing electricity if we were to face extended power outages.

I remember many years of hurricanes prep looking a lot less organized and a lot harder. I’m grateful to be in a place on our farm with good equipment, lots of good infrastructure which is so very far from where we started on this land less than 4 years ago and the “know how” to prep ourselves better and better every year.

Hoping for minimal impact and that all of our neighbors and friends and anyone in the path of the storm stay safe!

I know that look in my daughters eyes, the one where her eyes well up and her little lip quivers. I had been pushing her, I’ll admit it. It’s because she’s been talking about showing and barrel racing and even though I don’t have the budget for it now, someday I might. So I’ve been trying to help her see there is so much more to riding than hanging on and keeping your hands and heels down so when we can, she’s ready.

“This is just so hard and it’s so frustrating.” I don’t want it to be like that for her to where it makes her not enjoy it. But this is an Ellie pattern. She was the same with brushing her hair when she was little and then again learning to read and all the little things in between. When things are hard or annoying or aren’t happening after the first try, she declares she hates it & quits.  I told her, “be up there for you.  If it’s not what you want, get down, I’m fine with it. You can go back to just trail riding, we don’t have to work towards more.” She refused to dismount.

So I asked her how often she thought I wanted to sell the farm. Her response was, “you don’t.” I said “wrong.” Truth is, every day I  think about selling the farm. Not all day every day but every day. When my husband leaves for work at 430am, gets home after dark and then helps me into the late evening still, I want to quit.  When markets are slow and money is tight, I want to quit. When Mother Nature throws us constant curve balls, I want to quit. When I watch everyone around me taking vacations with their families, I want to quit.

But I don’t. We don’t.  And it’s for moments like this, the moments she’ll carry with her. The moments of resilience we teach her and the moments of resilience she experiences. The memory of building a bond with her horse and breaking bad habits and working through hard times and succeeding. She’ll carry this.  The times she’s watch us scratch and claw to stay standing on this farm, through seemingly impossible times, she’ll carry that.  It’s the teachable moments scattered throughout her childhood, that in her darkest moments in life, those memories of resilience will carry her through.

She wiped her eyes & the lesson carried her through.

One of the most requested videos I get asked to make is videos of our infrastructure because we use all shipping containers for every out building on the farm from our tools to feed storage to our brooder to walk ins and more.  We do all the builds, electrical and plumbing ourselves.

Here’s a little teaser before I show off a full tour of the veggie pack shed that we finished at the beginning of this year that has our walk in freezer, office, 3 walk in coolers, wash pack area and tool and garden storage!

I can promise you, I tried not to like him and I sure as hell didn’t want to love him. We were so different in so very many ways.  Everyone would say, “but what happens when he’s 70 and 80?  You’ll still be pretty young.” I heard them. And I thought about it. But I also thought about how in my previous relationships, I would make excuses for the horrible and at times physical fights we would have. I would excuse the men I was in relationships with, when they would say horrible things about my body and I’d tell myself “they just want me to be the best version of myself.” I thought if we had money, a nice home and a few happy moments scattered throughout that I was supposed to be grateful for that. Those moments made the horror worth it.

But the truth was, it was all lies I told myself.  And then he came along. And he would look at me like no one had ever looked at me before. He was thoughtful, always considering my wants and needs, even just as friends.  He made it nearly impossible not to like him. When he was my neighbor, I’d wake up in the morning and I’d find vegetables from his garden, on the hood of my car for me for the day. And when I was breaking a colt, I told him I wished I had a round pen. So for 2 weeks after work every day, he’d show up with lumber and he built me one.  Then he’d sit on the back of his truck with his tailgate down and a Coors Light in his hand and watch me work that colt.

Truth is, I never got to be myself until I met him. At least be myself, alongside of someone else. When those other relationships would end, I’d reclaim my independence, then and only then, being the best version of myself, the one I thought I had to change to appease all the others. Eventually a new one would come along and I’d conform again as they snuffed my flame.  It was a miserable cycle. But it led me to him.

And now, I stand facing him, holding his hands, and I’ll run my hands up his arms, coming in for a hug.  Over 9 years later, I’ve felt his body change during those hugs. His forearms & elbows and biceps, further worn and aging. But guess what, I’ve changed too.  But what hasn’t changed is how he looks at me & how he loves me & I hope it never will.

Many many long, late nights in my farming career, I’ve looked at her and thought, I couldn’t do this without her.  Ever encouraging, ever optimistic, ever empathetic, my girl is all the things you need when the going gets tough.

I’m proud to raise my daughter differently, to give her a life most only dream of. And yeah, she works hard. But she plays even harder, riding her horse on our trails, riding her quad down to the pond and fishing whenever she’d like, playing and creating. We have made many sacrifices to give our daughter this life.  And often times I wonder if the struggles are worth it. But then I see the moments and the resilience we’re teaching her. I see the lessons in the every day and I know that we are where we need to be.

We may not always farm commercially. But my daughter will always be a little farmer.  Resilient, strong, innovative, smart and caring and so much more.

The evolution has been painful.  If you had told me, sitting on milk crates on the deck, with this wide eyed baby girl with a half plucked chicken on her lap looking on, helping us get our own food on the table, that someday we’d be raising 4,000 chickens per year to feed our local community, I wouldn’t have believed you.

I’ll never forget when he finished my washing machine chicken plucker, not long after processing our first chickens by hand. I went down from 15 minutes plucking to 15 seconds. Only downfall was if you touched the washing machine when it was on, you got shocked.  And the day I had my own processing station with makeshift tables, I would’ve told you I hit the lottery.

It has been a constant evolution of growth, mostly outgrowing. Outgrowing those makeshift tables for a stainless work station, then a covered work space, eventually upgrading to cement floors and two completely different pack and wash sheds, one for poultry and one for veggies.  And it’s not just he and I and that wide eyed baby girl any more. It’s a team of us, that work tirelessly, day in and day out to feed our community. And luckily I traded that washing machine for a commercial plucker years ago.

I remember feeling like we’d never make it, we’d never have the things we needed.  I remember almost quitting, 1000 times.

I hate to tell you that it never gets easier “making it”. You’re still going to want to quit.  I still almost do. We still scrape by.

But I’m living proof that hard work gets you there.  Maybe not on everyone else’s timeline or even on the one you’d hoped. But you’ll get there.
