The Raising Wild Forest Chickens Series has launched and we want to share everything we’ve learned about successfully raising thousands of chickens to feed ourselves and our community over the years, with a special focus on raising chickens without coops and man made shelters.

Head to our website under the LEARN tab and join us for our first series!

Farrowing live in our forests with one of our seasoned moms!  We generally allow them to go unassisted. But farrowing in the dark poses different obstacles for the piglets. So I like to make sure they are clear from the hind end and up fighting to nurse. And I also like to make sure the nest the sow built is working in her favor and not hindering movement or trapping piglets underneath of her.

Our pigs are bred here, born here and raised here. That means that we know the origin of our pork and how it was raised and treated with 100% certainty from start to finish. We have been working since 2015, growing our breeding program and our pork program. Our pigs are raised naturally in the woods and rotated through forest sections. They forage on roots and tubers, bugs, grubs and different foliage. They are an incredibly important part of helping us thin our forest canopy to create silvopasture, as they uproot saplings and even invasive species like kudzu vines and chinaberry trees. 

We farrow pigs 1-2 times per year between April and October when the weather is best for natural, outdoor farrowing. Our sows farrow fairly unassisted, with us helping to make sure their nests have enough hay, the piglets aren’t getting tangled with their long umbilical cords and that they are all nursing by the time the sow is finished farrowing.

To control our populations, bloodlines and inbreeding we castrate our males at birth. This is least traumatic for the sow, as she’s still in a trance from the birth that she doesn’t even realize the piglets have left. Sows are INCREDIBLY protective of their piglets and can get VERY VERY upset when you take their pigs. The piglets also have very tiny testicles which lead to tiny incisions which heal quickly.  The constant access to colostrum after also helps the pigs heal more quickly than if we waited.

We do not vaccinate our pigs for anything and we will watch for parasites as the weeks go by, individually treating and not blanket treating so that we can continue to encourage strong, hearty bloodlines that thrive in forest environments with minimal human intervention.

Our bloodlines are hybrid sows that we’ve developed over the years that include Duroc, Yorkshire, Berkshire, and Mangalista.  We keep two boars for breeding and right now we have a pure bred Berkshire and a Hampshire. They are kept in separate forest sections from the sows and our grower herds and only go in with the sows for breeding and then are rotated back out.  We prefer to breed all groups at one time.

We harvest 96 pigs per year in our pork program currently.

4 years ago I was pregnant.  We were all excited, especially Ellie. Just like with everything else, I included her, along in the pregnancy journey.  She’d lay on my belly every night and press her ear to my belly.  We’d talk about how big the baby was and she’d ask how many sleeps until the baby would be here.

When I had Ellie I spent years battling the postpartum depression that ensued. Finally, when Ellie was about 3, I felt good enough and felt ready enough to welcome another baby. I have a sister I love dearly, I wanted Ellie to have a sibling too. We also felt like 4 would complete us.  So we tried again. And pretty soon after, we had baby number 2 on the way.

That was the plan until it wasn’t any more. No one knows why these things happen.

I’ve spent the last almost four years, every single month, wondering if I’m pregnant when my cycle comes around.  I’ve probably spent hundreds of dollars on pregnancy tests in the last 4 years, thinking each time I’m slightly late, will be the month.

What I’ve accepted though is that there’s a greater plan and I’ve learned over the years to understand that I’m good with this plan, whatever it is. But it doesn’t stop me from wondering what could’ve been or what might be.

What I do believe though, is that this is how it was always meant to be.  I was meant to have this wild girl. And then I was meant to have the pain and the sadness. But my wild one, was always meant to keep me grounded to bring me back to all things real and true.  She’s the one I find bridleless and bareback, flying with her horse in the setting sun.  She completed me long ago, allowing me to share a part of who I am, along with all that she is.

I think about that little baby girl leading that horse all those years ago. I think about watching Ellie grow into the little rider she is now and how that little baby she was, is so very long gone. Every day. I think about the one we lost too. But mostly I look at Ellie and in these moments, her blonde hair flowing in the orange and yellow sun, I know she has her dad and I, exactly where we’re supposed to be.

The first time we ever sold our pork was as Whole Custom Cut Hogs. Well, the first time we sold it legally. Back when we started years ago, we didn’t know what we didn’t know. Hell, the custom butcher we used didn’t even put the “not for sale” sticker on our meat.  We learned one day though when someone from the department of ag came and ran their own little sting operation on my poor hubby who had nothing to do with anything farm really.

I was at work and James was home before me and this guy from the department of ag stopped by our old farm. Posing as a hardcore home grown pork lover, he insisted on buying some pork. He said he saw on Facebook we had some for sale. James actually tried to give him a pack of chops to just try since I wasn’t home and he couldn’t get ahold of me. But the guy who we later learned was an inspector insisted on handing James a $5 bill. And as soon as James took the $5, the truth came out.

We didn’t have a livestock trailer back then to haul our pigs to the USDA, we barely had a pot to piss in.  So we offered our next batch as Whole Custom Cut Hogs and used that money to invest in a trailer. Since those first whole hogs, we haven’t offered them again. That is until now.

Over the years we have built our pork program up from 10 pigs to harvest per year to almost 100. And we sell all of our pork direct to consumer in retail cuts locally. But this fall, we just happen to have 10 extra hogs that are ready and just not enough freezer space because we raise a years worth of chicken just in the summer months and the walk in is slammed full of beef, pork and chicken.

So for the first time since 2018, we’re offering Whole Custom Cut Hogs. If this is something you have asked us about, now is your chance. 2 have already sold, bringing us down to 8 remaining. We’ll be offering them to our email list subscribers first to snatch up.  This available as on farm pick up OR Roebling, NJ pick up (for when I visit my mama later this fall).

If this is something you want, send us a DM with your email so we can make sure you’re on our email list so you can know first!  Hogs will be released mid week!

Visit whippoorwillfarmssc.com/wholehogs for info!

“What’s the worst that can happen?” he asked, when I told James how scared I was.  I told him, “The bank takes back the land.” He seemed unfazed by that possibility.  So I went with it.  I knew, after selling our first farm, we had just enough money left over to make the first 3 land payments.  We had three months to figure out where the money was going to come from.  James and I could only work so many hours at our off farm jobs and there was only so much we could do.  So we put our heads down and we worked.

For the last 4 years, we did all the things that a lot of people said we couldn’t do.  We did a lot of the things, even I didn’t think would be possible.  Now we gross, during good weeks, what we grossed in our first year, back on our first farm 5 years ago.

The stress, the worry, the struggle has never once dissipated.  In fact, all of those things have gotten bigger with every investment we make toward continuing this dream.  I look back at that short video clip in the beginning, when all this land was, was a big dirt pit, I can’t help but be amazed at us, my husband, myself, my daughter, our team.  4 years isn’t really that long at all, but in 4 years so very much has changed.

Most of all, I have changed. I have grown. And every day that I spend on this land, I get closer to figuring out exactly what I was meant to be doing. I haven’t found it quite yet. This isn’t the end game for me, farming. I have so many other gifts to share with the world. But what farming has done, what building this business has done, is allowed me to dig in deep. Dig deeply into who I am as a person. Farming has exposed my greatest flaws, faults and weaknesses. But in return, farming has exposed my greatest strengths too.  Owning a business and leading a team has challenged me as a person to show up every damn day, even when I didn’t want to.  The farm has forced me to face the hardest days and challenges, when I wanted to just run and hide. And in all of that, I have learned things about myself.  Things I never would’ve known, sitting at a desk, telling my superior, “yes” when all I wanted to do was scream “NO!”

4 years and so much has changed, including myself.

Four years on the Big Farm. 4 years of growing and learning and building. 4 of the most challenging years of my life. 4 of the most fulfilling years of my life.

These are my before and afters. The before and afters of so much that I silently envisioned.  James didn’t even see it in the beginning. I couldn’t explain to him what I saw that day we walked the property. “There’s no pastures. There’s not even any roads.  Whatchu gonna do with all these woods?” “Farm it,” I told him. 

And farm it, we have. Doing it completely different than anyone that walked this land ever has.  Finding the solutions when all that stood in front of us was difficulties.  Difficulties we faced, challenges we overcame.  I built the business as James chipped away at the endless to do’s on any and every one of his days off over the last 4 years.

Each of these before and after photos were taken standing the exact same place.  And although I envisioned the after, I could have never imagined the journey in between and how hard it’s been. But I never take the easy way out, my mom would attest to it and my dad watching down on me would agree.  There’s no room to follow game trails in my world, I was out here to forge new paths.  And I just so happened to find a partner in all of this that knows how to help me forge through when I feel trapped or stuck.

Tonight James told me we had just over a year left to pay on one of our loans we took out to build some of the early infrastructure on the farm. “We’re getting so close. I’ll just keep pushing and trying to make it happen.” His response, “you are making it happen.”

We all are making it happen. Including our loyal customers, like our Lowcountry Farm Box Subscribers, our weekly market shoppers, our restaurant partners, the guests who come and stay on the farm, our donors of the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand and the avid learners who sign up for my virtual and in person classes.  We appreciate all of you so much and every single one of you, helps us get closer to “making it happen,” every single day.

We’ll see you at the Forsyth Farmers Market tomorrow in Savannah!  There’s also a few whole hogs left for our whole custom hog sale too!

This class is how we choose our forest sections, how we transition our chickens out and everyone’s favorite question, how do we protect from predators and inclement weather and so much more!

If you buy eggs or our beef at any of our markets or through our Lowcountry Farm Box, you are an important part of the soil restoration and regeneration of this pasture ecosystem!  When we took over these pasture 2 years ago, they had been bush hogged for the last 10 years, with no other inputs or livestock impacts.  Much of the soil was bare, with very little organic matter.

Over the last three years we have tirelessly rotated our cows and our egg chickens, cover cropped, rolled out round bales of hay, given the pastures plenty of time off and repeated the cycle again and again.  After two years time, we are finally seeing huge amounts of organic matter in the pastures and beautiful grasses that grow to maturity quickly.  We’ve also noticed that the soil temperature in these pastures has decreased over the years as the dense grasses and added humus have helped to cool the soil, holding moisture in, even during the 105 degree, dry summer months.

Our pastures thrive and grow during the most difficult of climate conditions.  Through heat and drought they continue to grow and thrive to keep our livestock fed.  Through torrential rain, the well established root systems and grasses soak up the moisture, preventing run off and absorbing that water like a sponge.

Our farm is so much more than feeding livestock to in turn feed you.  It’s feeding the soil, nature, the native ecosystems and creating resilient, strong land for years to come.

Happy 1 Year On The Farm to Mike!

Last September, Mike's Mom texted me.  She told me her son was moving back into town and she wanted to bring him over to volunteer. He was quiet and stood in my kitchen while I cooked dinner.  I honestly felt like he didn't want to be here at the farm, anywhere near Ridgeland and especially not in my kitchen trying to convince me that he wanted to volunteer.

Mike had been struggling for some time.  He finally decided, if he was going to get on track, giving his mom a chance to help him line some things up, would be one of the best ways to help him get back on his feet.  I reluctantly agreed, a little nervous that I'd spend my time teaching him and one day, he'd be gone.  After a month of hard volunteering, I told mike if he was ready, I would hire him full time.

The week after he earned his first paycheck, I was sure he wasn't going to show up for work.  But he was there, rain or shine, never late, on his bicycle pulling up the driveway.  Mike and I spent a lot of time together in his first few months on the farm.  I'll never forget, in one of our hard labor days together he said, "Yeah, I just have no idea who would want to work outside all day long, every single day."  I looked over and waved, "Hey!  It's me.  I do."  We both got a good laugh.  As I got to know him more, I really started to look forward to seeing him on the farm.  And Ellie and James did too.  Mike can talk to anyone about anything.  And he's always joking and kidding around.

As Mike continued to work hard and save up, he bought a truck from James and I.  It was the truck that Ellie had learned to drive in.  Jokingly, as he often did with Ellie, he asked her to move his truck.  I was out in the garden, and I looked up and saw his truck moving with no driver in sight and started to panic.  Finally I saw the littlest farm girl with a shit eating grin looking over as she pulled by.  We all got a big laugh that day.

We're so happy to have Mike apart of our farm family.  It's been an honor and a pleasure to watch him grow with us for the past year and I look forward to working outside with him, in all kinds of weather for years to come! 😬

While Victoria, Phoebe and myself (& baby Roman 😍) worked market this morning, Joseph, Victoria, Mike and Ryan worked hard getting 6,000 of the 10,000 sweet onions we’ll plant this season in the ground!

I remember when I thought 100 onions would be PLENNTYYY.  Then I remember last year when we thought 5,000 would be more then enough.  I haven’t been right once!  This year we’re doing 10,000.  Honestly if it wasn’t for row space in our no till gardens, we’d do more. But this will be good for this year until we expand again.

Most of these will be harvested before the bulbs are very big in size in early 2024 for our restaurant clients as Spring Onions.  As we grow them and harvest the Spring Onions, it will naturally thin them, allowing the onions that were closer in proximity to bulb out.

We practice the same method with our root vegetables, planting more densely and then thinning as smaller bulbs and allowing others to grow and expand a little longer. This not only saves space, but allows us to offer multiple finishes from the same planting and veggie.

It’s an awful labor intensive job but luckily, not every day looks like this on the farm.  We’ve got 4,000 more to go in the ground tmrw and then a few hundred of each broccoli, collard and Swiss chard but the big planting for fall is almost over. Soon we’ll be just maintaining with weekly direct seeding and a few hundred plants per week as seedlings.

I’m so proud of our team we’ve got right now.  The ones pictured, mentioned and even those not in this post.  We’ve all been incredibly busy making sure the community is fed!

For the past almost 10 years, I’ve been living in an RV.  I actually met my husband as his neighbor living in an RV park.  There are lots of reasons to love small, minimalistic living.  But with each perk, has come lots of sacrifices as well.  Small space living, long term, is not for the faint of heart and over the years, the lack of a kitchen with elbow room has slowly worn on me.  I’ve struggled to cook in the RV for years, especially cooking from scratch.  The busy schedule of running the farm, James working full time, no space to spread out and cook and an unreliable oven and a stove with just a couple burners has really turned me off from cooking.  It is hard to start meals during the day, when I am covered in chicken and pig poop, traipsing in and out of the RV to check things, turn things, baste things AND try to remember I was cooking in the first place.

A couple of weeks ago, James took an old stove and microwave someone was throwing out and he installed it, in our meat processing area!

My goal since then, has been to try to cook at least dinner each day using only veggies and meats from the farm.  My goal has also been to focus those dinners on all the things that my customers always struggle with cooking.  As someone who hasn’t really cooked for the last 10 years, or as an actual grown up (I was in my early 20’s when I moved into an RV!), if I can cook, anyone can.

So this past week, I roasted my first whole chicken ever, in my whole life.  A chicken I raised myself and then harvested, plucked by hand and processed for a class I am teaching.  It came out PERFECTLY.  Today, I baked our chicken wings.  I made them for all the staff working and everyone raved about them.  I even made scratch ranch dressing for dipping them.

Someday I dream of having a small house.  Nothing crazy, maybe 1,000 square feet.  But until then, I’ll continue manifesting, we’ll continue saving money for it and I’ll continue to perfect my cooking, in this very forgiving, outdoor space where I can be as messy as a beginner cook needs to be!

*recipes in comments!*

As the seemingly never ending summer has faded behind us, in a year that has felt, it was filled with nothing but challenges, I look around at the farm in the setting sun and can’t help but be proud of all we’ve achieved this past season.

The summer weeds we thought we’d never tame have given way to beautiful fall crops on our no till farm. The forests and silvopastures are filled with the last 1,400 chickens we’ll raise for meat for 2023.  Our last farrowings of 2023 pulled us well over our goal for our 2024 pork program.

4 years ago we moved here, to absolutely nothing but dense woods. No roads, no water, no electric, no anything. And for 4 years we have hustled to build this place.  So much of what we struggled with in the beginning comes wildly easy now. And what we thought was a challenge back then is nothing compared to what the universe throws at us these days. As our farm and business become more complex, larger and mature, so do the types of problems we encounter.  But regardless we push through.

3 of the 4 garden spaces are tamed and nearly all completely planted for fall, with rows in continual production, harvest and flipping for weekly direct seeding. The longer growing crops are in the ground with successions that followed and more on the way.  The 4th garden is mostly covered and resting, with a few rows peeking through. Our high tunnel is still giving us tomatoes from plants that went in all the way back in May.  And in between the tomatoes, the arugula has been a chef and customer favorite.

After almost 4 years as no till, bringing no equipment in to break up the soil, the oldest of the gardens (photo 5) struts her stuff as the younger of the gardens still gain their footing in their no till journey.  We’ll still work to lay cardboard, combat high weed pressure and soil inconsistency in the younger gardens. But over time, they will find their way too.

Can’t say I’m sad to start to bid farewell to 2023.  But I’ve learned this year that it’s ok to be ready to say goodbye to things but also recognize how those very things have shaped you along the way.  Love and hate can both coexist. And they can both be apart of who you become.

One big question we always get asked is “is having a PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand Profitable?” The answer to this question is complicated. Profitable to who?  The backyard gardener?  A commercial farmer with payroll to fill?

The question I think most people are asking is, “can you afford to full time farm and support your family and employees by just stocking the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand?”

The answer to that would be a hard NO.

But we work insanely hard to make sure that we are at least somewhat profitable (for a farm) in all of our other revenue streams. Those include our Subscription Service which functions similar to a CSA, restaurant sales weekly, multiple farmers markets, agritourism, consultations and online classes and speaking engagements as well as online monetization and sponsorship.  We also have mutual aid shares that help fund the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand and donations as well which greatly contribute to its success.  Through all of that hard work, the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand is able to exist. The money we get at the stand rarely covers the cost of the food we put out, but it’s not about that really and that’s what’s important for folks to take away.  The stand is apart of the farm ecosystem and it only functions properly when all the other parts of the farm are functioning properly too.  But the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand couldn’t exist on its own, to fund an operation as large as ours.

But it can exist when all the other parts are working together with the purpose being to make sure that EVERYONE in our community has access to nutrient dense, natural food grown and raised by their neighbors.

And if you’re interested in being apart of the change that helps feed people in our hyper local community, you too can donate to our PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand at whippoorwillfarmssc.com/donate!

Don’t just buy food, buy food that’s grown regeneratively, locally and grown using the most thoughtful environmental processes along the way!  Find a local farmer near you today putting in the effort and support them!

Depending on the needs of each of our groups of chickens we raise for meat, we will either just push them around in their 3 acre sections. Or if a particular group seems to run through forage more quickly, we’re always ready to pivot and put sections on rest more quickly and open new spaces. Grazing lanes are great ways to move chickens when they need access to fresh forage but aren’t completely ready to move off a space.

Since we do not raise our chickens in coops, we let them choose their own forest home base area, usually in the thickest part of the forest.  We always keep access to their home base for them and instead of completely moving them, we change the fencing around them.  We use grazing lanes to focus them in small areas to move from space to space and back to their home base.

One more week for these Freedom Rangers and then they’ll head to our USDA processor and their silvopastures and forest will go on rest after a fresh broadcast seeding of fall cover crops!

The next time this area will see livestock will be months from now in the spring!

All I gotta say is theses days, we are professionals. Pig load out didn’t always look like this. 🤪 but after many years, we’ve gotten it down to a science. It just takes practice.  And my biggest piece of advice… a pig isn’t going anywhere it doesn’t want to go… make trailering a normal activity for them. Get your chute in place and use it often along with gate systems. Eventually you’ll be loading pigs with ease too!  And the stress level for your pigs will be so much lower if it’s just part of the normal day to day for them!

My personal phone rang earlier today with a number I didn’t know.  I never give out my personal number but I was feeling adventurous so I answered.  The caller said, “I have your number here on a piece of paper from last week some time and I’m sure it’s important but I can’t remember why.”

Eventually after a few minutes he remembered why. A colleague of mine had shared my number with him. He was a fellow SC farmer who raises pigs and as of lately, he’s been feeling the strain of the economy more than usual.  I immediately was interested in talking to him.

I find it hard to connect with many of my colleagues.  They flood their social media with “look how great all of this is and how wonderful our farm is!” But no one ever talks about the struggles, especially the financial struggles. No one ever says, “sales are down and I’m worried about paying my feed bill.” No one ever outwardly says, “we don’t make enough money to eat the food we raise.” No one ever admits, “this is harder than we thought it would be.” And even in person, for some reason, I seek connection and true meaningful conversation but it’s often surface level & it leaves me feeling like I must be missing something if we have struggles.

But I know it’s not true because I’m far too bright and business minded to be the only who struggles at times. And whether it sounds arrogant or not, if I haven’t financially found the secret with farming, no one has.

But there was something so refreshing today, getting a call from a complete stranger and them saying, “I don’t know that things have ever been this tight financially.” I immediately felt all of what they were saying so deep within my soul.  30 minutes of honest conversation later, I said, “I’m sorry, I didn’t catch your name.” But it didn’t really matter his name or his farm name or where he lived or what markets he sold at. What mattered was that for 30 minutes 2 strangers shared honest conversations about their farms and hopefully helped and inspired each other to continue along the way.

Farming is HARD. Raising livestock is EXPENSIVE.  The challenges are PLENTIFUL.  The financial gain is MINIMAL. And its ok to be HONEST about it.

I tore apart the shipping container which for us is like what most people have a garage or attic for. I was hunting for our camping gear. It had been 6 years since we used it last. 6 years almost to the date when we took our last camping trip. The last trip happened right before the goal of raising food for ourselves really started to shape into reality. A year after that, things morphed into raising food for others and our new reality of quitting my corporate career, working part time and full time farming set in. But that reality meant we really couldn’t afford the food we were raising and we definitely couldn’t get away.

Since then we’ve kept our heads down and hustled. James still works his off farm job and I not only am not working part time outside of the farm, but we’ve built a business that is run and managed, no longer just by myself but by a team of people we built and continue to develop.

And although the stresses of the business and the financial strain continue to be ever present, we continue to steal back moments for us.  What we’ve built, including our team, are giving us these moments back that we’ve worked so hard for, for so very many years.

Nothing extravagant for this farming family. Just a primitive camp site an hour from home, fishing poles and piles of fire wood. But these days, when we cook over flame, it’s our proteins we’re grilling, our eggs we’re eating, our veggies we’re slicing. And although we might still eat the less popular and cheaper cuts, we finally can afford to.  And we can also can afford to step away. If even for just a couple of nights, a stone throw from the farm, as a family.  Making memories, trying any and every fishing spot we could find, watching our daughter fall asleep by the fire with nothing but the breeze blowing and the ocean crashing behind her.

6 years has gone by in the blink of an eye. But we are a testament that if you stay focused and keep hustling and working, you absolutely will get your moments back. Not over night, but it will come. And memories like this, will fold in and over and under the memories of building and growing, failing and succeeding, the memories that have made our story.

In the spring we did something different in the name of permaculture. Instead of wasting garden space on a huge vining plant, we threw our luffa seeds at the base of some of our trees in our power line easement. It’s a spot that our meat chickens actually go through and fertilize at different times of the year and a space that has rich, well draining soil.  It also gets some sun as well but not full sun.  We wanted to see what it would be like growing not only chickens for meat on the forest floor level, but oaks dropping acorns from above and luffa gourds thriving in between and throughout.

And to our surprise, the luffa plants started to grow!  And grow!  And grow some more!  They have grown ALL over some of the trees and have produced huge luffa gourds!  Some of these trees were deciduous and have lost their leaves as the weather has changed and in the process have left the luffa vines on them little protection from frost as transpiration rates have nearly halted. Those gourds on our deciduous trees have now died and dried.  But some of the trees that the vines were growing on were our Southern Live Oaks which are nearly an evergreen and have continued the process of transpiration helping protect vines from freezing temps. And believe it or not, the vines in our oaks although not producing new flowers, are still green with green ripening gourds!

Today we got to pick some of the dried luffas from the trees!  We just needed a big extension ladder and a fearless barefoot helper!  There’s still lots growing that we will just have to patiently wait for!  It was a fun experiment and we shook out more seeds from the dried luffas beneath the trees again to see if they’ll continue the trend this coming summer when it’s time!  Wonder what other weird places we’ll plant veggies and fruit this coming summer!

“A farmer can’t do this without the support of the people.” Will Harris, another leader in regenerative agriculture recently said this.  I haven’t been able to stop thinking about it since I heard it.

So many times people say, “we support what you do” or “we think what you’re doing is great!” But often times, you never see those folks showing up week after week at market.  Believe me, I love support from afar, I love sharing what we do and impacting others to shop local in their local communities.  But what I want to see is the locals here that say, “we support what you do,” come out to market and show that support.  Because the farmer cannot do this, without the support of the people.  As a farm, we have stayed true to our roots in keeping it local, truly local, providing for our local community & not offering shipping.  We believe there is a lot of difference to be made right here in our backyard. But we cannot do it without the support of the people.  We cannot make the difference our world needs without the support of the people.

Of course, our products are more expensive than the grocery store. Because they are far superior. I stopped at the gas station today for a bag of pretzels, peanuts & water & spent $13.  That’s how much one pack of our sausage costs, that can easily feed multiple people a far more nutrient dense meal than those awful vending machine snacks I ate for breakfast today driving home from the butcher.

Tomorrow we’ll be in Savannah at Forsyth Farmers Market from 9am to 1pm.

Nothing worth doing is ever easy. We all have a thousand excuses why we can’t shop local or make a market. But WE CANNOT DO THIS WORK WITHOUT THE SUPPORT OF THE PEOPLE.  Nothing about farming regeneratively is easy or cheap. But I can promise you, it’s always worth it.

Tomorrow, make it a point to shop local. Whether with myself or anyone else. Because we cannot make a difference without the support of the people.  Tomorrow please come out and help be the change you wish to see here, in our local Lowcountry Community!

Our egg chickens are in leased pastures and we are limited on predator control tactics we can employ. No loud livestock, no dogs, no trapping. So instead we have to get creative.

But it works!

Also it’s important to note that often times, the financial commitment of a guardian animal isn’t always worth it if attacks are few and far between and can be mitigated with less expensive solutions.  Even if we owned these pastures, a dog or other guardian animal might not be the answer.  Dogs can be a costly investment, especially after training them as proper guardian animals.  A lot of times, if you just think outside the box, you’ll find other solutions!

We’ll keep our dogs in the woods with our meat chickens and keep getting creative with our egg layers!

Tomorrow morning in the rising sun, as we harvest for all of our restaurant deliveries to head out just before the holiday, we’re going to harvest extra produce to share on the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand!  While we realize we can never match grocery store prices and conventional grown produce and meat prices, it’s always been a goal of ours to provide for EVERYONE no matter their economic status.  The PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand is just one of the many ways we try as a farm to make sure we’re giving an opportunity for EVERYONE to have access to really, natural, nutrient dense food.

When you shop with us at market, through our Lowcountry Farm Box Program, through pre order gate pick ups at the farm or as a restaurant partner, you continue to help us be able to provide for not only you but so many others.  Whether you’re buying a $5 bundle of collards from us,  a large monthly subscription, or you’re leaving the spare change you can afford, in the box at the stand, EVERY contribution to our farm helps contribute to EVERYONE having access to real food and helping us take steps to healing our food system and our communities.

Tomorrow, Wednesday, November 22 from 12pm until gone at the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand at 870 Tillman Road, Ridgeland 29936 please come out and TAKE WHAT YOU NEED and PAY WHAT YOU CAN!  There will be meats in the freezer, eggs and of course a selection of veggies.

Follow along as we prepped, picked and stocked the stand!

Happy Thanksgiving from our farm family to yours!

Going against the grain of societies norm to be the change you wish to see in the world is never an easy task. It’s often met with great resistance.  I would know first hand.  I have fought many battles locally for acceptance and support from my community for the work we do and still fight battles for acceptance to this day.  But I’ve never experienced the battles that my friend Mady in Laurens, South Carolina has had to face in her small town.

Mady is an urban farmer breaking no laws or regulations, farming on her small piece of property in Laurens, South Carolina. Mady has a weekly subscription for her veggies, sells to restaurants and donates veg to local non profits.  Mady has 3 kids, 1 of whom has special needs.  Her urban farm allows her to make a small living while providing for others so she can be there for the frequent appointments her son Boone has.

On any given day Mady wakes up to tags on social media of disgruntled neighbors angry because her front yard is a garden and not a lawn.  She has faced vandalism to her plants, strong resistance from the town to be able to put a small donation based produce stand up at her walkway and of course, the many complaints she gets to her face and behind her back about her eyesore garden.

Yesterday morning however, she woke up to a new kind of attack.  Confirmed by the authorities, someone broke into Mady’s yard in the middle of the night and stabbed her three goats to death.  Muddy footprints, finger prints, video footage and wound examination confirmed, this was a deliberate attack.  It came just a week after another Facebook post surfaced of more neighbors angry about her front yard garden.

I couldn’t be more disappointed in Laurens, SC right now. I’m disappointed because as a collective, you’ve let the negative voices overpower the positive when it comes to Mady and the work she does for her local community.  For anyone that supports her initiative you’ve stayed silent for far too long.  The time is now to stand up and support her.  Mady isn’t going to quit, in fact her fire burns more fiercely than before.

Ways to support her work & her right to farm and provide are listed in the comments!

There’s a time in my life I don’t remember many details from, bits and pieces find their way into my memory.  It was a time of turmoil in my life, a lot of anti-psychotics and hospitalizations.  It was a time of my life when my cheeks were stained with tears, far more often then they were stretched from smiling.  A time of my life when I nearly ended it. I’m a true testament to the saying of “I promise it gets better,” because it does.

Over 10 years have passed since that time but I’m still healing.  But one of the biggest things that has helped me in my healing has been serving others.  My farm is my refuge and it has brought me the greatest healing.  While it does at times bring me great heartache and hurt, the healing of this farm, far outweighs all the struggles.  I serve others in many ways on this farm.

I serve my father who passed away not long after my last hospitalization through the native ecosystem regeneration work we do, as my father was a biologist and I feel most connected to him on this land.  I serve my daughter through creating a legacy for her and teaching her how to leave the earth in a better condition than we found it and to serve others in the process.  I serve my husband by giving him a chance to do work he loves, building, growing, creating and staying in touch with the roots his family established long ago in the soils along the South Georgia coast.  I serve my employees by being 100% committed to caring for them and doing my absolute best by them, as they care so much for our business, our farm and our family.

I also serve my community in perhaps one of the most special relationships of servitude I host.  All of the other relationships I mentioned above, leave an impact I see in almost a tangible measurement.  But the community is one that stretches so much further and wider than what I could ever imagine seeing.  It’s the impact that brings me the greatest hope, because the work we share leaves our mark in places I’ll never know about and never realize.  The ripple effect that goes long beyond the gates to this farm.  Thank you for being apart of my healing. And if you’re struggling, hold on. I promise, it gets better.

We already have bins and bins of wrapped and age labeled gifts ready to go out under the tree.  And we’ll be doing a Whole Chicken Drive and Holiday Breakfast Bundle Drive to put our meats out on the stand! It was probably overkill but we weren’t going to chance it.  Tonight after harvesting ALL DAY for restaurant deliveries tomorrow, we rushed around hooping and covering thousands of feet of rows with frost cloth.  For the past year I’ve invested thousands of dollars into frost cloths and I wasn’t going to let “let’s just see what happens” come between us and making sure everything we’ve worked so hard to grow made it through.  4 gardens, 10,000 feet of garden rows and we got it all finished just as it was getting impossible to see in the dark.

Phoebe and Mike stayed late making sure it all got done alongside of me. It was a crazy busy day.  I sent them my mileage walked for the day and told them highest mileage tracked gets lunch on the farm tab!  Phoebe clocked almost 5 miles, I came in at almost 7 but Mike had us both beat coming in at 8 miles!  He already said he’s looking for a lunch special priced at “market price” 😂.

In years past, we’ve seen devastation from frosts. It’s not always about the frost itself but the length of time it stays below freezing.  And while the forecast often gives us one temperature, we’ve learned at our farm, it will most likely always fall a few degrees lower than the predicted temps.  Also because our temperatures fluctuate so much, going from very warm one day to freezing the next, it’s always good to cover plants that just aren’t as hardened off to the cold as they would be if it was consistently cold.  Even if doesn’t drop enough to truly warrant the effort we put out, at least we tuned up our frost cloth skills for the next time!

I’m so glad we’re prepared this year just in case Mother Nature wants to make it a really wild winter.

I was helping her wash her back in the shower tonight. She said, “Mom, I really thought I was going to die.  It was like a nightmare. I just closed my eyes until it stopped.” Her body was still a little sore from this morning.

If you missed my instagram stories, Ellie and Willow had an accident this morning.

Just like most mornings, Ellie got up to ride. Before 8am and before I’d even sipped my coffee she was on her horse. I walked out in the field & started coaching her. She wasn’t doing much of anything, just trotting a circle. But it was slick from the morning frost, more so than I realized and Willow lost her footing & slid out, onto her side, throwing Ellie down with her.  It tossed Ellie at the perfect angle to twist her foot in the stirrup as she went down and Ellie’s foot got stuck in the stirrup.  I watched on as Willow jumped up, startled by Ellie hanging at her side and took off running, dragging Ellie along with her.  After about 60’ Ellie dropped and I caught up to her. Ellie immediately jumped up and with tears in her eyes and panicked screams she told me, “I’m ok! I’m ok!” I grabbed her and pulled her helmet off of her and examined her face and head. I unzipped her coat & checked her body. “What about Willow?!” she cried. “Willow is fine, we’ll grab her after we check you.” I took her remaining boot off and her socks and nearly stripped her down right in that frosty grass. She was, fine.  Her helmet did it’s job and the Carhart jacket she was wearing, gave her plenty of padding as she bounced against Willow’s back leg.

And in the seconds as I watched this unfold, the memories flashed in my head. The baby in my belly as I broke that Marsh Tacky.  Her very own first horse at 6 months old.  The day she handed over a fat wad of cash to buy Willow from money she’d saved herself selling eggs and modeling for Duluth Trading Company.  The falls, the injuries, the ER visits, the accidents, the triumphs.  The lessons. The close calls that have always become our lessons.

The lesson today… mom ordered some loads of sand for footing in that pasture so Willow has better footing.  The triumph… she was totally ok.  And she got back on.  Always get back on.

Tonight we loaded the last of the chickens for our 2023 poultry program to head up to the USDA Processor.  This year we have faced MANY challenges when it comes to our poultry and I’d be lying if I said I wasn’t looking forward to a 3 month break before we start back up with 2024’s poultry program.

 We used to process a lot of poultry on the farm. But this year, we took all of our chickens, aside from what we processed for ourselves up to the USDA.  Because we sell over state lines our poultry had to be USDA inspected. And because our processor is 3 hours away, we try to do large groups of chickens from March until December to minimize our drive time.

The most common reaction we get when we tell people that we raise our chickens in the forests without any coops or man made shelter is intense skepticism.  Folks assume our losses are incredibly high due to predators. And while we do lose chickens to predators, we lose chickens to other issues too. Like when we lost over 50 out of 700 in one of our batches in the first 24 hours after arrival due to longer than normal shipping time.

After the final count tonight on the trailer, in spite of all of the challenges, 89.9% of the chickens we ordered this season will make it or have made it to the freezer, leaving us at a 10.1% overall loss.  It’s impossible to have perfect batches.  There will always be loss on a farm. There will always be predators. There will always be challenges out of our control.

But I would choose this method of raising our chickens a thousand times over as opposed to raising them in chicken tractors or raising them as “free range” in a chicken house.  The value of the end product, the nutrient density and the impact these chickens have on our forest systems as they move through, will always be far greater than all of the challenges we face.

To our loyal customers, we are so proud to work hard, day after day, through challenges seen and unseen to provide you all with the most absolutely unadulterated poultry product available in our area.  And shout out to our team for a very successful, albeit challenging 2023 Poultry Season!
A quick look at our pack shed and market prep!

I’m so excited to announce that in January, I’ll be attending the South Carolina Women In Agriculture Conference in partnership with Clemson Cooperative Extension.  But I won’t just be in attendance, I will be the Keynote Speaker for the conference!

I’m looking forward to meeting lots of other women in agriculture and cultivating community at this event with you all!  I’ll be sharing my story and touching on how cultivating my connection with the earth, my fellow farmers and my community has helped to lead me to my true purpose in farming and feeding my community and helping lead the charge for regenerative farming in South Carolina.

I’d love to meet you!  If you’d like to attend the conference, please visit https://www.clemson.edu/extension/scwagn/events/conference.html to register for the event!

I’ll be speaking on January 20th at the lunch, but I’ll be attendance both days.  I so hope to see you there!

Also on January 23rd, I’ll be one of the farms on the SC Agritourism 2024 Annual Conference where I’ll be hosting an extensive farm tour and discussing regenerative agriculture on our land.  If you’d like to register for this event, you can do so by visiting scagritourism.org - although this tour is geared toward other producers, everyone is absolutely welcome but you must register in advance!

2024 is getting off to an exciting start!

A week post accident and Ellie was back in the saddle!  10 days post accident and Willow and Ellie completed their first big trail ride together clocking almost 5 miles!

Horses changed my life growing up. They truly made me the resilient, strong woman I am.  This is the life I dreamed of for my daughter.  Lessons of life being hard, knocking you down, hurting you, breaking you, but learning to dust yourself off, find your confidence and trust again and continuing to push until you achieve.

Parents; if I could give you any advice, save your money on fancy Jordan’s and Stanley Cups and iPads and iPhones and all the other junk kids don’t need and invest your money into putting them on horseback.  We may never have money to show or compete or have fancy gear but we have the life lessons. And that’s so much better than all the junk we could ever accumulate.

When I’m in the thickest, hardest moments of this life, I never think to myself how much we’ve achieved. I often think of how much I haven’t achieved or accomplished honestly. But it’s a glimmer like this, with my daughter under a droopy Live Oak that reminds me, dammit Marissa, you’re doing it, if only for this moment, you’re living out one of your dreams.

Keep dreaming, keep working hard and you’ll have your moments too. Glimmers they might be, but they are still there. And when you see them, capture them and hold them and they will get you through.

Our farm is so much more than a place that we raise food to feed our community. It’s also a place that we teach skills to pass along to others to help them learn to be self sufficient and honor the earth and all she produces along the way.  We pass these skills along to our daughter but also to our staff.

Yesterday after a long 10 hour day on the farm, we were lucky enough to have our friend Bill drop off some deer for all of us to share on the farm. We taught Victoria and Joseph how to skin their deer down and quarter it. They’ll finish cutting it down today. Ellie and I worked to debone ours. We’ll pass along all the deboned meat to Ryan who will take it and combine it with our pork fat and grind us all burger. 

Not even the dogs were left out, who eat raw and LOVE venison, especially when it’s fresh and they spent the evening occupied with their ham and shoulder bones.

Although we don’t usually have time to hunt, our friend Bill and other friends usually always try to hook us up every year with deer, wild pig and even gator when they get it.  We’re always grateful to have the space to process the animals down, plenty of mouths to feed on the farm and an opportunity to teach new skills to our team.

Since December 1st, we have serviced 75 of our Lowcountry Farm Subscribers for their monthly meat, veggie and egg subscriptions with goods from the farm. We’ve delivered to our restaurants each week AND we even started a second farmers market on Saturdays at the Port Royal Farmers Market.

It’s been a wild ride of a December so far this month.  But the team has handled all of the struggles and pressures with extreme grace and we have hit the mark, with just a few mistakes here and there along the way, which is always remarkable.

After picking for our restaurant partners yesterday we assessed the gardens this morning. We still have Lowcountry Farm Boxes to go out tomorrow, 2 more markets to prep for and 40 veggies bags for Meals on Wheels to head out on Monday. So we decided that we need to move the date of the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand Holiday Offering to Friday, December 22nd.  We realize it’s a little closer to the 25th than we would have liked.  But what’s most important to us, is that folks get the best selection available and unfortunately, we just would have too limited a quantity this week if we went forward with it as planned.

On Friday, December 22nd, we will be stocking the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand with lots of beautiful veggies!  We’ll also be offering FRESH whole chickens that we processed on the farm, ready to go into your ovens for your holiday meal on the 24th or 25th AND breakfast meats for your holiday breakfasts as well! We’ll also be putting a bunch of wrapped and age labeled toys under the tree at the stand!

Everything will be out at the stand as a TAKE WHAT YOU NEED and PAY WHAT YOU CAN basis. But we are asking our local community for help. While there are a lot of non profits and churches helping during the holidays for folks locally in Hardeeville, Bluffton, Hilton Head Island and Savannah, our farm serves as an important food hub to folks in further outer lying areas who may not have the transportation or ability to get to those other places.

If you’d like to help contribute toward our whole chickens and breakfast bundles we’ll be putting out, please head to whippoorwillfarmssc.com/christmasonthefarm to learn more!

We practice no till on our farm.  This means we do not disturb the soil in our gardens. We don’t use tractors or  tillers, we don’t even typically pull weeds.  Instead when beds become overrun with weeds we cover with silage tarp until the weeds die and the weeds too go back into the soil as future nutrients.  We don’t even broad fork any more now that our gardens are established and the soil has become better and more loose from years of no till practices.

One of the most important aspects for us is layering.  Layering helps us feed our soil and the microbes in it, so they can feed our plants. And to keep weeds down, mulching, season after season, plays an important roll too.

Not only does our mulching feed the soil as it breaks down year after year, but it also helps with water retention during dry spells, drainage and erosion control during rainy seasons AND weed suppression.

We do most of our mulching in the winters when it’s cooler and the warm season weeds have died back.  It’s a lot more tolerable to get mulching done when it isn’t crazy hot out.

We find using the tractor or skid steer to dump into multiple wheelbarrows at once, allow us to get the mulching down more quickly. Something else different from our farm other than a typical market garden… we always keep our rows wide enough for a two wheeled wheelbarrow to fit down. This makes working in our gardens so much more enjoyable for our team.  We could certainly save financial resources, like mulch and generate more revenue with additional growing spaces by narrowing our walkways.  But this has always been the one thing the staff begs for in the gardens and so it’s a small gesture to make working in the spaces easier on them.

“The Potting Shed,” got a major glow up this past week.  Actually, 2023 has been the year of investing in all kinds of garden glow ups.

After sitting just absolutely crammed to the brim with plants in the Potting Shed last spring (photo 3), we decided as a team, come hell or high water, we couldn’t operate out of it for another season with seedlings.  So after we finished putting up the new high tunnel, we went ahead and ordered a second smaller version which is now “The Greenhouse.”

We try really hard to listen to suggestions from our team, because let’s face it, they are the ones in the field. Something that was desperately needed was more room for soil blocking, potting up and tool storage. So this past week, we removed all of the corrugated plastic from The Potting Shed, replaced it with T1-11, had volunteers come out and paint it, knocked down some pine trees AND added 10 extra feet of lean-to.  We still have grow lights inside on shelves so it will still be used for germinating seedlings but it’s now a much more functional space.

We have 4 gardens, soon to be 5, spread out around the farm. We have them spread for wildlife buffers and to allow us to incorporate rotational grazing next to them with our livestock as well as incorporating fruit trees around them.  But with the buffers, that means A LOT of walking back and forth. We needed storage space closer to the back gardens for bulky wheelbarrows and tools that could be dedicated to those gardens.  So we finished up at the Potting Shed and moved to the Field Garden shed.  Today we completed it!

We bought our land 4 years ago after selling our first small farm that we ran our business off of for 1 year.  The big farm was nothing but overgrown forests. There were no roads, no water, no electric.  We have kept our heads down and hustled to get this far. And although the projects are never ending and often times feel like we just can’t get our footing, it’s always good to look back at how far we’ve come, even just in less than a year.  James is back to work tomorrow but this farm wouldn’t be anywhere near what it is today without his dedication to always helping on his days off.

Let’s clean out our brooder!

Every year we brood out 4,000 chickens in our shipping container turned brooder. Although we practice the deep litter method, every four weeks we still completely clean the brooder out.  We use a livestock trailer to get all the chickens out. Then we come in with the skid steer.  We know we’re properly doing the deep litter method when all of the shavings seem dry all the way through and the floor underneath is nice and dry too.  We go back-and-forth back-and-forth sweeping in the edges and then scooping it as we go. The last step is to completely sweep it out get the water and feeders clean and ready and then let our chickens back into the breeder. These gals are the 2024 egg layers to add to our flock and they have a little more time left in the brooder before heading to the pastures.

We are so happy to announce that the PAY WHAT YOU CAN Produce Stand is stocked and ready for our neighbors to come and take what you need and pay what you can!  Merry Christmas Everyone!

What you’ll find on the stand today:
🎄 Gifts for kids of all ages from people all across the country who contributed
🍗 Fresh Whole Chickens in the Coolers with Recipe Cards from our Farm
🐖 Breakfast Sausage Meats in the Freezer from our Farm

🌱 Purple Top Turnips, Daikon Radish and Mustard Greens from our Friends at Pecan Hill Plantation

🌱 Lettuces, Radishes, Bok Choy and Kale from our friends at Vertu Farm

🌱Scallions from the farm and other veg well continue to fill in as we harvest today!

Please come out to 870 Tillman Road, Ridgeland, SC 29936 - first come first serve!  All we ask is that you please only take WHAT YOU NEED so that we leave plenty for those joining after us!  1 whole chicken per family and 1 breakfast meat per family please!

As a reminder the farm entrance is not open to the public but you can easily access the stand before the gates.

We hope you all have a wonderful Christmas and a Happy New Year!

She flip flopped back and forth with the idea. She was going and then she wasn’t and then she was going again. Until she wasn’t. I asked her when it was just us, “Ellie, why do you keep changing your mind?  What is making you not want to go?” Her answer, “I just don’t want you and daddy disappointed if I go.” It’s the most Ellie thing she could’ve said. Ever empathetic, always thinking about others feelings and well being before her own.

I said, “Ellie, do you know what “people pleasing” is?  It’s when we do things and make choices to make other people happy, no matter if it makes ourselves happy or not.  Sometimes you have to “people please” like when you’re asked to clean things up that you don’t feel like, or go somewhere with mom and dad when you don’t feel like it.  But sometimes, you have to make choices just for yourself, purely for your own happiness and no one else’s.  We all have to have balance in our lives where we make choices with others in mind and at times when we make choices, selfishly, with only ourselves in mind.  I WANT you to be selfish right now. We’re offering you a chance to make a decision for your happiness only.  Don’t worry about what we want, what do YOU want?”

She answered quickly, “I want to go.” So Friday evening we watched her leave the porch and get in the car with my brother in law to head up to my mom’s and my sister’s for the holiday. Her door closed and I immediately felt sick. She had gone and stayed so many times, but there was something about not having her around for Christmas that suddenly had me regretting my little pep talk to her.  She deserved Christmas magic and her cousins and her grandma and Zia. She deserved an opportunity to do something other than feeding hogs on her holiday.

As they pulled away, I started crying inconsolably. So much crying I made myself sick. I realized this was it, this was what it feels like, when they start making their own choices, start spreading their wings.  And I realized the despair and joy I felt in this moment for her was only the first of many moments I’ll feel this throughout the rest of her life.  Wanting her to fly but wishing she’d stay.

We raise 4,000 chickens per year and sell them direct to consumer locally through farmers markets and our Lowcountry Farm Box subscription service.

We like our chickens to forage more than anything, but we still supplement them with certified organic grain. They get a little less than 1/4 pound per bird per day and they are always really happy to get their supplementation. This provides them with additional minerals and protein to guarantee a balanced diet and healthy, happy birds while they rotate through our forests and pastures.  We also like to spread the feed on the ground in areas that need more impact from their pecking, scratching and movement. The chickens impact our soils in hugely beneficial ways by crimping and crushing down cover crops, keeping bug populations under control while they are in each area of the farm they spend their time (especially when they are next to our gardens), suppressing weeds and fertilizing as they go. Once they’ve impacted an area enough, it’s on to the next spot and the current section goes on rest!

This time last year we faced unprecedented cold temps for our region. The chickens shown in this video were just 1 week away from processing at this point. The challenge wasn’t keeping the chickens alive, it was keeping 100 gallons of water thawed and available to them in the forest each day.

Because we never face temps like this, our water lines had to be blown out because we don’t bury them as low in our region. We relied on our irrigation pond and fires to keep these chickens warm and content and hydrated.

Meat chickens are done for the season now and will start back up in March. So far this winter has been fairly normal and mild again. But at least we know, every year we farm, we continue to prepare ourselves for extreme weather!
If doing a better job training your four-legged friends is a goal of yours for 2024, Farmer Ellie is here with some tips to get you started!

Happy New Year!

If 2024 has you craving a change, this post might be for you!

We’ve been working hard over the past few weeks to assess our needs and goals for 2024.  After lots of team meetings, we’ve posted our 2024 job openings!

If meaningful and challenging work sounds like what you’ve been looking for, head to Whippoorwillfarmssc.com/joinourteam and see if any of these jobs sound like a good fit!  Apply by sending your resume to the email on our website!

Many of our crew have been with us for multiple years, learning and growing into new roles and responsibilities over time. It brings me, as a business owner and a leader, great pleasure to help to continue to elevate people to their potential and help them reach their goals. This isn’t just a place for a paycheck, this is a place to come and build yourself as we build our farm and community.

At this time, jobs are open to local folks only as we do not have the ability at this time to sponsor or house anyone.

We hope you all have a wonderful 2024!
The Farm Girl is home!  And she’s been just soaking in being home after a week away and hanging with all her furry and feathered friends.  So good to see her wild self around the farm again!

For the last two years I have been looking for another horse for both Ellie and Willow (Ellie’s horse). If you’ve never bought a horse or haven’t bought one in the last few years, horse shopping is PAINFUL and that’s putting it mildly.  From dishonest sellers to over proud owners and over priced horses, the market has been wild.  I have stayed patient and stuck with my gut as I skimmed over horse after horse after horse.  I even paid for Pre Purchase Exams that showed way more than the seller would’ve ever disclosed. Maybe hundreds of dollars wasted, maybe thousands of dollars saved. Who knows, bottom line is when you’re putting your kid up on a horse, it better come as advertised. 

Ellie doesn’t need two horses. But horses love a partner.  Willows pasture partners have been the cows for the last two years. And while that’s fine, she really needed another horse, especially because the cows come and go and move a lot more frequently than Willow needs to.

We’ve always taken great care of our horses and all of our livestock.  We don’t spare much expense when making sure they have what they need.  And this has given me an opportunity to have a great relationship with my vets.

I mentioned again to one of my vets recently that I was still looking for a partner for Willow and another horse for Ellie and she had one in mind.

Whiskey comes to us from @scadequestrianteam after being apart of their beginner riding program for the last almost 10 years. He’s ready to retire from the jumping ring and enjoy a life of trails and having a little girl that spoils him.

We got to bring him home today and introduce him to Willow. And I’d say we’re all pretty happy to have him here, especially Willow!

I feel so grateful and even flattered that SCAD would even consider us as a home for Whiskey.  He is proof that if you’re patient and you keep going, eventually you’ll find what youre looking for.  Welcome Whiskey to our farm family!  We can’t thank @scaddotedu enough and one of our awesome vets for helping make this happen!  Can’t wait to see how retirement looks on Whiskey! and yes… he is as huge as he looks and makes Willow look like a pony 😂

Chick season will be here before you know it!

So you wanna be a chicken farmer?

Yea, chicks are cute and fluffy and chickens are fun and lovable creatures who produce delicious eggs and/or meat!  But there’s a lot more to it than that!

Pasty Butt is just one issue you may encounter when raising chicks!

Pasty Butt happens to about 5-10% of our chicks. And we raise thousands every year. And while you can help prevent it by adding ACV to water and making sure they have a clean and warm brooder with the correct temperature and humidity levels, it can still happen. So know what to look for and be prepared!  Pasty butt can be deadly as it can block the vent, preventing chicks from excreting waste. So as long as you’re checking vents and watching for signs and helping address them as they arrive, your chicks will thrive!  We have found that after about a week of life, it’s no longer an issue and chicks have moved past the pasty butt danger zone!

Warm water works great too. But for us, we prefer to treat them immediately as we see them, instead of worrying about going and grabbing warm water every time we see a chick that needs treating. So we keep coconut oil at the brooder and it does the trick. I also prefer to not use gloves and just wash my hands after because I can feel more easily and be so much more gentle without gloves.

Come find inspiration and cultivate connection with so many other women farmers and Women in Ag in the South East at the @clemsonscwagn Annual Conference!  I’ll be the keynote speaker and I’d love to see you there!

Head to clemson.edu/extension/scwagn/events/conference.html to register!

Here’s a little glimpse into my keynote!

“When I was asked to be the keynote speaker for this event, I was incredibly flattered.  But before I could even bask in the feeling of pride, pure self doubt flooded it all out.  I got off the phone that day & thought to myself, “what could I possibly say to these women that is inspiring?”  If I’m being honest, I’m coming off the hardest year for our business & we’ve only just made it through year five.  I thought to myself, “should I tell them to run?  Should I tell them to quit while they are still ahead?  Run, run like hell?”  I thought of the last year & I thought how many times it nearly broke me.  I thought about the last 5 years and all of the tears.  But I also thought about how, by some miracle, I was still standing, our business growing more & more every single year.  Yeah it was the hardest year yet, but it was our biggest too.  This past year showed us incredible growth & I’m not just talking about financially.  I’m talking about the growth of myself.  So many times this year I dropped my head into my hands thinking, “how much more does my character need building?  Like really?  How much stronger could I possibly become?”  Well, to my surprise, A LOT stronger.  What I decided I wanted to share with you all, the value I could bring most was honesty. As we’re all here desperately trying to find our place & connect with each other & even ourselves in a world that so much more often feels disconnected than not, I wanted to bring you honesty.  Honesty in how I got here, how I struggled & how I’ve kept fighting. Sometimes scraping and clawing my way back up, but somehow finding my way again, in the face of great adversity. Honesty in my experience in the hopes that some day when you find yourself against the ropes, taking blow after blow, you too can find that fight within yourself.”

I hope I’ll see you there!

Chicks are very vulnerable and take special care and attention in their first weeks of life.  They are extra sensitive to heat and humidity and a lot of those factors can help be controlled by the way you give them access to water.  We brood out anywhere from 600 to 800 chicks at a time, every 4-6 weeks. It takes a lot of extra time changing out small, 1 gallon water containers 2x-3x per day for all those chicks. But they are just too little for bigger containers as they can drown in the basin of them.

To be able to use the bigger containers anyway, we line the basin of the large 3 gallon containers with small rocks. It allows the chicks a safe place to climb and perch to get water, keeps them safe and dry and warm and it also cuts chore time WAY down for us, only having to wash and fill waters 1x per day.  It also keeps the brooder cleaner and dryer as there is no accidental splashing from the chicks falling into the basin and trying to get out.  This keeps their temperature regulated and the humidity in the brooder regulated too.  You’d be surprised how much of a difference just having some damp bedding can make in the environment for them and their success growing into strong adult chickens.

As they get bigger, you can reduce the amount of rocks to allow them more room or you can remove the rocks all together!  Spring is just around the corner, so give this a try in your brooder this coming year and let us know if it helps!

Earlier today, I looked out into the gardens and the team was buckled down, rain gear on, winds whipping, harvesting for our Lowcountry Farm Boxes.  James and I rode by on the tractor on our way to repair fence lines.

Today was one of those days when it was dangerous to be on our farm. Because of how we farm in the forest, there’s very few places, including our gardens, that you walk that you aren’t under trees.  Today like usual we worked. The only thing that was different though was no one except James and myself went out on fence lines and in the dense forests because of the trees and limbs falling.  We worked fence lines making repairs most of the morning, limbs cracking over head and falling nearby as we worked. We loaded pigs in the trailer for processing, slipping and sliding into the electric fencing at the chute more times than I could count.  A day like today makes me think about how some days we’re literally out here nearly dying, trying to feed others.  Days like today make me wonder if I’ve lost my mind. Am I insane to care so deeply about this way of farming and providing for others?  Maybe. I still can’t decide.

If you are local to our area and you too believe, like us that this kind of work and this kind of food is important, you’ve come to the right place. We’ll be opening more Lowcountry Farm Box subscriptions this month. This is THE best way you can both get exceptional quality products from our farm AND support our work.  Whether you are able to subscribe for $175, $275 or $375 monthly, every commitment level matters to us. Your subscription is so much more than just food. It’s nutrients for your family, meaningful work for some of your neighbors and it supports a family, out there, giving it their all, day in and day out trying to leave their slice of land, far better than they found it.

Make it a point to shop local this year and make choices that help better impact your community as a whole.

Visit lowcountryfarmbox.com for all the details and to add yourself to the waitlist!

And to our current almost 70 subscribers, we appreciate you all so very much!  Your commitment to us keeps us going on days like this!

In honor of Phoebe’s 1 year back on the farm as the Farm Manager, we’re kicking off her shout outs with one of my favorite videos featuring her of all time!

This video showcases how we take waste from local fisheries and plant beneath our heaviest feeders for the best long release natural fertilizer you can find!

It’s been a crazy week!  After welcoming Whiskey, our newest equine addition home and trying to get him settled, battling storms and now myself battling bronchitis, it’s been a doozy!

I’m so excited though that amidst the chaos, we also welcomed some extra help on the farm this past week too!  My sister and her family are here!  Their first day in the lowcountry was quite an experience with the horrible weather we had. But they are starting to settle in and I’m so excited that she’ll be a new face at our Saturday Market in Savannah for you all to meet!

Come find my sister Alisa and Victoria and baby Roman at @forsythfarmersmarket tomorrow and of course Ryan at Port Royal Farmers Market.

We’re prepping for a hard freeze on the farm this week and have seen a slow down in our winter crops. So veggies will be limited a little bit.  Ryan will have the bulk of our veggie offerings in Port Royal. But you’ll find plenty of our organic fed chicken, pork, beef and even eggs at the Forsyth Farmers Market tomorrow!

This past week Phoebe celebrated her 3 year mark with our farm and her one year mark as the Farm Manager.

Phoebe started with me 3 years ago as a volunteer. She was taking her life in a different direction and trying to find her footing and some meaning. Three days per week she’d come out and bust her ass for free, simply because she believed in the mission and most of all she believed in me.  We grew close during her time, chatting on the porch, sharing a beer on a Friday.  We’d brainstorm and bounce ideas off of each other. At times, I’d cry to her when things were hard.  She’d encourage me and push me forward and help me find the humor.  Phoebe has seen me at my best and my lowest on the farm. She’s seen my truest, ugliest parts, the growing pains of a leader, the mistakes and she’s seen so much of the triumphs.

I’ve watched her change and grow too, learning the most special parts of her. I’ve learned her kindness towards others and how she nurtures her friends and her friendships.  Doing for others and going out of her way for others, fills her and fuels her. She’s thoughtful and honest and the kind of friend you want to have on your team.  But more than that, she’s driven and she’s so smart.  And she’s the kind of leader who leads by example.

Phoebe has grown into her role this last year with such grace. She has almost single handedly grown and managed our Lowcountry Farm Box program by adding 30+ subscribers in the last year, almost DOUBLING our monthly revenue from this program.  She has cultivated relationships with chefs, landing us weekly accounts with restaurants we feel so lucky to be partners with.  She has helped develop our team, assisting in training 6 new employees in just this last year.  Phoebe handles all things post production on the farm from customers to products to inventory management to supplies and more.

I honestly can’t believe how far we’ve come together. Often telling the greenhorns, “look, you have no idea how hard it used to be.” But she stuck by me and us and the mission. Thanks for a great year, Pheebs. We love you.  Mentoring and leading you has been one of the best parts of my farming journey thus far.
